145.01  DUTIES.
   The police force of the City shall preserve the peace, protect persons and
property and obey and enforce all ordinances of Council and all criminal laws
of this State and the United States.
(ORC 737.11)
145.02  POLICE AND SANITARY JURISDICTION EXTENDED TO PUBLIC PARKS.
   The police and sanitary jurisdiction of the City is hereby extended to
provide for the protection of all public parks, owned and used by the City and
located beyond the corporate limits of the City.
   The violation in such parks of any of the provisions of these Codified
Ordinances any resolutions pertaining to the police and sanitary jurisdiction
shall be prosecuted in the Municipal Court of the City.
(1967 Code 105.03)
CHAPTER 146
Juvenile Police Bureau
146.01   Establishment; appointment of Officer.
146.02   Purpose; compliance with regulations.
146.03   Duties.
146.04   Compensation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES

      Unlawful purchase or consumption of alcohol - see GEN. OFF. Ch.

      Offenses relating to juveniles - see GEN. OFF. Ch.

146.01  ESTABLISHMENT; APPOINTMENT OF OFFICER.
   There is hereby created within the Police Department the Juvenile Police
Bureau.  The Bureau shall contain a Juvenile Police Officer who shall be
appointed from the ranks of the Police Department by the Director of Public
Service-Safety.
(Ord. 44, 1968)
146.02  PURPOSE; COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
   The Juvenile Bureau shall have the duty to engage in activities which are
aimed at the prevention, reduction and control of juvenile delinquency and
shall cooperate with Federal, State and other public and private agencies
having like objectives.  The Bureau shall comply with and conform to standards
and regulations promulgated by the Ohio Youth Commission pursuant to the
provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 5139.
(Ord. 44, 1968.)
146.03  DUTIES.
   The Juvenile Police Officer shall perform among others the following duties:
   (a)   Apprehension of offenders.
   (b)   Interview of juveniles taken into custody and of the parents or
guardians of these juveniles.
   (c)   Investigation of offenses or alleged  offenses involving juveniles.
   (d)   Police disposition through clearance and/or referral of juveniles to
agencies or to juvenile court.
   (e)   Preventive surveillance of juvenile gathering places.
   (f)   Development of working relationships and programs with schools and
community agencies.
   (g)   Police Department representation in community planning and public
relations in regard to children and youth.
      (Ord. 44, 1968)
146.04  COMPENSATION.
   The Juvenile Police Officer shall be compensated according to the prevailing
rate for a similar rank and comparable position within the Police Department.
(Ord. 44, 1968.)
CHAPTER 147
Fire Department
147.01   Investigation of cause of fire.
147.02   Spreading of fires through negligence.
147.03   Hearing on cause of fire.
147.04   Arrest of persons suspected of arson.
147.05   Power to compel attendance of witnesses.
147.06   Power to administer oaths.
147.07   Investigation may be private.
147.08   Age limit for original  appointment.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Appointments; probationary period and age - see Ohio R.C. 124.27, 124.30,
124.42
      Promotions - see Ohio R.C. 124.31, 124.45 et seq.
      Fire Chief suspension - see Ohio R.C. 124.34, 124.40
      Hours and leave - see Ohio R.C. 737.21, 4115.02
      Sick leave - see Ohio R.C. 124.38
      Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
      Composition and control - see Ohio R.C. 737.08, 737.21
      Schooling, buildings and equipment - see Ohio R.C. 715.05, 737.23 et seq.
      Fire Chief - see Ohio R.C. 737.09
      Appointment of emergency firemen - see Ohio R.C. 737.10
      General duties - see Ohio R.C. 737.11
 
 
147.01  INVESTIGATION OF CAUSE OF FIRE.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall investigate the cause, origin
and circumstances of each fire occurring in the City by which property has been
destroyed or damaged, or personal injury or loss of life has occurred.
   (b)   The investigation shall determine whether the fire was the result of
carelessness or design, and shall be commenced within two days, not including
Sunday, if the fire occurred on that day.
   (c)   The Chief shall forthwith notify the State Fire Marshal, and within
one week of the occurrence of the fire shall furnish him a written statement of
all facts relating to its cause and origin and such other information as is
required.
   (d)   The Chief and his subordinates, at any time of day or night, may enter
upon and examine any building, premises or vehicles where a fire has occurred,
and other buildings, premises or vehicles adjoining or near thereto.
(Ord  70, 1978.)
147.02  SPREADING OF FIRES THROUGH NEGLIGENCE.
   (a)   No person shall set, kindle or cause to be set or kindled, any fire,
which through his negligence, spreads beyond its immediate confines to any
structure, field or wood lot.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
147.03  HEARING ON CAUSE OF FIRE.
   The Fire Chief, while conducting his investigation, may take or cause to be
taken, if necessary, the testimony on oath of all persons supposed to be
cognizant of any facts, or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter
concerning which the investigation is being made, and may cause such testimony
to be reduced to writing.
(Ord. 70, 1978.)
147.04  ARREST OF PERSONS SUSPECTED OF ARSON.
   (a)   If the Fire Chief is of the opinion that there is evidence sufficent
to charge a person with arson or a similar crime, or with a violation of
Section
147.02 relating to the spreading of fires through negligence, he may arrest
such person or persons or cause same to be arrested and charged with such
offense or offenses.
   (b)   The Chief shall furnish the State Fire Marshal or assistant fire
marshal and the Police Department with such evidence, along with the names of
witnesses, and a copy of material testimony taken during his investigation.
(Ord. 70, 1978.)
147.05  POWER TO COMPEL ATTENDANCE OF WITNESSES.
   The Fire Chief may summon and compel the attendance of witnesses to testify
in relation to any matter which is a proper subject of inquiry and
investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document.
(Ord. 70, 1978.)
147.06  POWER TO ADMINISTER OATHS.
   (a)   The Fire Chief may administer an oath to any person appearing as a
witness before him.  No witness, not a possible suspect to the crime of arson
or other similar crime, shall refuse to be sworn or refuse to testify, or fail
or refuse to produce a book, paper or document concerning a matter under
examination, or display contemptuous conduct after being summoned by the Chief 
to appear before him to give testimony in relation to a matter or subject under
investigation.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section may be summarily punished by the Chief
by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or commitment to the
City jail until such person is willing to comply with the order of the Chief.
(Ord. 70, 1978.)
147.07  INVESTIGATION MAY BE PRIVATE.
   Investigation by or under the direction of the Fire Chief may be conducted
in private.  The Chief may exclude from the place where such investigation is
held all persons other than those required to be present, and witnesses may be
kept separate from each other and not be allowed to communicate with each other
until they have been examined.
(Ord. 70, 1978.)
147.08  AGE LIMIT FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   The Civil Service Commission is hereby authorized pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 124.42 to award an original appointment to the Fire Department to any
person between the age of eighteen and thirty six years.
   (b)   Nothing herein shall be interpreted or construed to alter,  modify or
in any way change all other requirements for an original appointment to the
Fire Department as defined by the Ohio Revised Code or by other ordinances of
the City.
(Ord. 28, 1984.  Passed 3-19-84.)
CHAPTER 149
Board of Public Utilities
149.01   Establishment and composition.
149.02   Compensation; bond.
149.03   Duties.
149.04   Sale of City's personal property.
149.05   Director of Utilities.
149.06   Legal defense of officials.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Authority to establish - see Ohio R.C. 735.03
      Water and sewer regulations - see S. & P.S. Chs.
925,
929
 
 
149.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby created and established a Board of Public Utilities which
shall be composed of three members who shall be appointed, with the consent of
Council, by the Mayor.  The Mayor shall appoint one member for a term of two
years; one member for a term of four years; and one member for a term of six
years.  At the expiration of each term of office an appointment shall be made
for a term of six years.  In case of vacancy by death, resignation or removal
from the corporation of a member of such Board, the Mayor, with the consent of
Council, shall immediately appoint a successor to fill the vacancy for the
unexpired term. 
(Ord. 66, 2016.  Passed 10-3-16.)
149.02  COMPENSATION; BOND.
   The members of the Board of Public Utilities shall serve without
compensation and no bond shall be required of such members. 
(Ord. 66, 2016.  Passed 10-3-16.)
149.03  DUTIES.
   The duties relating to the management and operation of the municipally-owned
waterworks and sewage disposal plant and system conferred upon the Director of
Public Service-Safety by the Ohio Revised Code shall be and are hereby vested
in the Board of Public Utilities.
(Ord. 66, 2016.  Passed 10-3-16.)
149.04  SALE OF CITY'S PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   The Board of Public Utilities shall sell any and all personal property owned
by the City which in the Board's opinion is not needed or fit for use by any
department under its control and of less value than one thousand dollars
($1,000), provided such sale is first approved by the Board of Control.  The
Board of Public Utilities shall conduct such sale as it shall deem proper and
may hire an appraiser if it so desires in the determination of values of such
property.
(Ord. 17, 1958.)
149.05  DIRECTOR OF UTILITIES.
   (a)   Council hereby creates the position of  Director of Utilities.
   (b)   The qualifications to fill the position of Director of Utilities shall
be as follows:
      (1)   The Director of Utilities shall be a resident of the City, or
become a resident of the City, within one year of his/her appointment.
      (2)   The Director of Utilities shall have five years' experience in
operations, maintenance or supervision of a municipal water or sewer plant.
      (3)   The Director of Utilities shall have a Class III water/sewer plant
license.
   (c)   The Director of Utilities shall have the following duties:
      (1)   To administrate the Water and Sewer Departments.
      (2)   To maintain communication with the department head for each
department on a daily basis to insure smooth operation.
      (3)   To enforce the Board's policy, rules and regulations.
      (4)   To supervise office staff and billing procedures.
      (5)   To supervise customer relations.
         (Ord. 65, 1989.  Passed 10-16-89.)
149.06  LEGAL DEFENSE OF OFFICIALS.
   (a)   "Water and Sewer Department Official" or "official", within this
section means members of the City Board of Public Utilities, and the Water and
Sewer Department heads.
   "Act or omission" within this section means an act or failure to act while
conducting the business of the City Board of Public Utilities while an official
in the Water or Sewer Departments.
   (b)   No official shall be protected by this section if the official is
charged, accused or sued for theft in office, or fraud.
   (c)   Each Water and Sewer Department official shall be entitled to paid
legal fees up to and including five thousand dollars ($5,000) for legal
representation when the official is sued for an act or omission and the
official has been sued individually.
   (d)   Each Water and Sewer Department official who is sued shall submit a
copy of the complaint to the Claims Committee of Council which shall determine
if the complaint qualifies the submitting official for legal fees.
   (e)   Upon a finding that the submitting official is covered by this section
the Claims Committee shall introduce a resolution to Council to pay legal fees
in accordance to this section.
(Ord. 42, 1986.  Passed 11-17-86.)
CHAPTER 151
Board of Park Commissioners
151.01   Establishment and composition.
151.02   Vacancies and removals.
151.03   Organization.
151.04   Disbursements.
151.05   Control and management of parks.
151.06   Expenditures of moneys.
151.07   Rules and regulations.
151.08   Establishment and extension of parks and other facilities. 
151.09   Employees.
151.10   Park Fund.
151.11   Contracts.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
      Authority to establish - see Ohio R.C. 755.01 et seq.
      Playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et seq.
      Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
      Police and sanitary jurisdiction extended to public parks - see ADM.
145.02
      Thompson Park - see ADM. Ch.
165
 
 
151.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Board of Park Commissioners.  The Board shall
consist of three members who shall be electors of the City and who shall be
appointed by the Mayor.  Such members, who shall serve without compensation,
shall be appointed for terms of one, two and three years respectively, and
their successors shall be appointed for terms of three years.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.02  VACANCIES AND REMOVALS.
   In case of the death or resignation of a member of the Board, the Mayor
shall immediately appoint a successor to fill the vacancy for the unexpired
term.  The Mayor may remove, with the consent of a majority of Council, any
member of such Board for incompetency or official misconduct.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.03  ORGANIZATION.
   The Board of Park Commissioners, after the appointment and qualification of
its members, shall elect one of such members President and another Vice
President, who, in the absence or disability of the President, shall perform
his duties and exercise his powers.  The Board shall make its own rules, its
meetings shall be open to the public and all questions acted upon shall be
decided by a yea and nay vote with the name of each member voting recorded on
the journal.  No question shall be decided unless it is approved by a majority
of the Board.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.04  DISBURSEMENTS.
   All disbursements of money by the Board of Park Commissioners shall be made
by the City Treasurer upon warrants drawn by the City Auditor, and no warrant
shall be drawn by the Auditor or paid by the Treasurer unless it is approved
and attested by the signatures, in their own handwriting, of the President and
Secretary of the Board.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.05  CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT OF PARKS.
   The Board of Park Commissioners shall have the control and management of
parks, park entrances, parkways, boulevards, connecting viaducts, subways,
children's playgrounds, public baths and stations of public comfort located in
such parks, of all improvements thereon, and the acquisition, construction,
repair and maintenance thereof.  The Board shall exercise exclusively all the
powers and perform all the duties in regard to such property vested in and
imposed upon the Director of Public Service-Safety.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.06  EXPENDITURE OF MONEYS.
   The Board of Park Commissioners shall have the expenditures of all moneys
appropriated by Council or received from any other source for the purchase,
acquisition, improvement, maintenance, equipment or enjoyment of all property
mentioned in Section
151.05, but no liability  shall be incurred or expenditure made unless the
money required therefor is in the Treasury to the credit of the Park Fund and
not appropriated for any other purpose.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.07  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Board of Park Commissioners may adopt and enforce regulations as to the
proper use and protection of all property mentioned in Section
151.05 and the improvements thereon, and may impose penalties for the violation
of such regulations.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.08  ESTABLISHMENT  AND EXTENSION OF PARKS AND OTHER FACILITIES.
   The Board of Park Commissioners may establish or extend parks, parkways,
boulevards, connecting viaducts, subways, public comfort stations, children's
playgrounds, and public baths located in such parks, within the City or the
territory contiguous thereto, and may acquire or appropriate, in the manner
provided by law, the necessary real estate for such purposes, and in the same
manner may appropriate, for parkway or boulevard purposes, any street, avenue
or public way of the City.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.09  EMPLOYEES.
   The Board of Park Commissioners may employ a secretary, general
superintendent, engineer, clerks and other necessary employees for carrying
into effect the purposes of its creation, and the Board shall fix the
compensation and term of service of such employees.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.10  PARK FUND.
   All moneys received by the City from taxation or otherwise, for the purpose
of acquiring, constructing, equipping and maintaining parks, park entrances,
parkways, boulevards, connecting viaducts, subways, children's  playgrounds,
public baths and stations of public comfort located in such parks shall be
deposited in the City Treasury and transferred by warrants on the City Auditor
to the credit of the Board of Park Commissioners in a fund designated as the
Park Fund.  All expenditures incurred by the Board shall be by warrant of the
City Auditor drawn in pursuance of the regularly authorized  attested voucher
of the Board.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
151.11  CONTRACTS.
   The Board of Park Commissioners, in the letting of contracts, shall be
governed by Ohio R.C. 735.05 through 735.09.
(Ord. 32, 1964.)
CHAPTER 153
City Planning Commission
153.01   Establishment and composition.

CROSS REFERENCES

153.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a City Planning Commission which shall consist
of eleven members, as follows:  the Mayor, the Director of Public Service-
Safety, the President of the Board of Park Commissioners and eight residents of
the City, who shall serve without compensation and shall be appointed by the
Mayor for terms of six years, each.
(Ord. 6, 1971.)
153.02  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the City Planning Commission shall be such as are
conferred and prescribed by the laws of the State and such as are conferred and
authorized from time to time by Council.
(1967 Code 153.02)
153.03 STREET VACATION FEES.
   (a)   At the time of an application for a street vacation is filed with the
Planning Commission, there shall be deposited with the City Auditor, the sum of
$500.00 to cover the costs of investigation, review, approval of the
application and cost of preparation, approval and filing of the street vacation
ordinance including postage and publication expenses. Such sum shall be
deposited and credited by the City Auditor to the General Fund.
   (b)   $100.00 of the deposit shall go to the Planning Department for the
application fee. $150.00 of the deposit shall be used by the Planning
Department to cover the cost of postage and publication fees.
   (c)   $250.00 of the deposit shall to City Council to cover the cost of
postage and publication of the legal notice.
   (d)   The unused portion of the $500.00 deposit will be returned to the
applicant after the process is completed.
(Ord. 47, 2012.  Passed 9-26-12.)

CHAPTER 157
Board of Health
157.01   Establishment and composition.
157.02   President Pro Tempore; meetings.
157.03   Term of office.
157.04   Powers and duties.
157.05   Voting.
157.06   Health Commissioner and public health nurses; powers and duties.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Creation of Board - see Ohio R.C. 3709.05
      Contracts with other cities or health districts - see Ohio R.C. 3709.08
      Orders, regulations and emergency measures - see Ohio R.C. 3709.21
      Health, safety and sanitation - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
521
 
 
157.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   A Board of Health for the City Health District is hereby established.  Such
Board shall be composed of five members, who shall be appointed by the Mayor
and confirmed by Council, and who shall serve without compensation.  A majority
of the members shall constitute a quorum.  The Mayor shall be the President of
the Board by virtue of his office.
(1967 Code 157.01)
157.02  PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE; MEETINGS.
   The Board of Health shall, at the first meeting in January of each year,
elect one of their number President Pro Tempore, who shall preside in the
absence of the Mayor and shall do and perform all duties incumbent upon the
President.  The Board shall meet for the transaction of business at least once
in each calendar month, and as often as is necessary for the prompt and
thorough transaction of its business.  Special meetings of the Board shall be
called by the President or by three members thereof.
(1967 Code 157.02)
157.03  TERM OF OFFICE.
   The term of office of the members of the Board of Health shall be five years
from the date of appointment and until their successors are appointed and
qualified, except that those first appointed shall be classified as follows: 
one member shall serve for five years; one for four years; one for three years;
one for two years and one for one year. Thereafter, one shall be appointed each
year.
(1967 Code 157.03)
157.04  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Health shall have all the powers and perform all the duties
granted to or imposed upon boards of health by the laws of the State or the
provisions of these Codified Ordinances, or by any ordinance of the City.  The
Board of Health shall enforce or cause to be enforced all laws of the State,
together with all ordinances and regulations of the City in connection with or
in reference to the public health, the prevention or restriction of disease and
the prevention, abatement or suppression of nuisances.  The Board of Health
shall determine the salaries of its employees.
157.05  VOTING.
   The members of the Board of Health shall vote upon all questions submitted
to the Board unless excused by request.
(1967 Code 157.05)
157.06  HEALTH COMMISSIONER AND PUBLIC HEALTH NURSES; POWERS
AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Health shall appoint a Health Commissioner who shall perform
such duties as required by law and the Board of Health.  The Board may also
appoint as many registered nurses for public health nurse duty as, in its
opinion, the public health and sanitary conditions of the City require.  The
registered nurses shall be known as public health nurses.  Council may
determine the maximum number of public health nurses to be appointed.  The
public health nurses shall perform such duties as may be required from time to
time by the Board of Health.
(ORC 3709.14, 3709.15)
CHAPTER 158
Drug Commission
158.01   Establishment and composition.
158.02   Duties and powers.
 
CROSS REFERENCES

158.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Drug Commission consisting of five members. 
The members of such Commission shall serve without compensation and shall be
appointed by the Mayor for terms of four years each, except that the term of
two members of the first Commission shall be for two years.
(Ord. 32, 1974.)
158.02  DUTIES AND POWERS.
   The duty of the Drug Commission shall be to devise ways and means to
adequately cope with drug abuse in the City area and to submit recommendations
concerning such to Council for its approval.  The Commission shall also have
such powers and duties as are conferred and authorized from time to time by
Council.
(Ord. 32, 1974.)
CHAPTER 159
Traffic Commission
159.01   Establishment and composition.
159.02   Duties and powers.
 
 
159.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Traffic Commission consisting of five members,
all of whom shall be electors of the City.  The members of such Commission
shall serve without compensation and shall be appointed by the Mayor for terms
of four years each, except that the term of two members of the first Commission
shall be for two years.
(1967 Code 159.01)
159.02  DUTIES AND POWERS.
   The duty of the Traffic Commission established by Section
159.01 shall be to devise ways and means to adequately cope with traffic
conditions in the City and to submit the same to Council for its approval.  The
Commission shall also have such powers and duties as are conferred and
authorized from time to time by Council.
(1967 Code 159.02)
CHAPTER 161
Community Relations Board
161.01   Establishment and composition.
161.02   Term of office.
161.03   Meetings.
161.04   Executive Commissions established.
161.05   Inter-Group Relations Commission; composition, meetings.
161.06   Inter-Group Relations Commission; duties.
161.07   Commission of Employment Practices; composition, meetings.
161.08   Commission of Employment Practices; duties.
161.09   Definitions.
161.10   Unfair employment practices.
161.11   Authorized exemptions.
161.12   Investigations: hearings and enforcement.
161.13   Office requirements and expenses.
161.14   Loyalty oath.
161.99   Penalty.
 
 
161.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   A Community Relations Board is hereby created.  Such Board shall consist of
twelve members, all of whom shall be appointed by the Mayor, to serve without
compensation.  No official of the City shall be eligible to serve, excepting
the Mayor, who shall serve as permanent Chairman.  (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.02  TERM OF OFFICE.
   In the original appointment of members, one-third shall be appointed to
serve respectively for one-year, two-year and three-year terms.  Thereafter,
appointments shall be for a three-year term.  (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.03  MEETINGS.
   The Board shall meet not less than monthly, except during the months of July
and August, on such dates as it shall determine.  Other meetings of the Board
shall be held upon call of the Chairman, or as may be determined by the Board. 
It shall elect its own Secretary annually.  It shall adopt by majority vote
such rules as it shall deem expedient for the conduct of its business.
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.04  EXECUTIVE COMMISSIONS ESTABLISHED.
   The work of the Board shall be carried out by two Executive Commissions: 
The Commission of Inter-Group Relations and the Commission of Employment
Practices, whose duties are hereinafter set forth.  (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.05  INTER-GROUP RELATIONS COMMISSION; COMPOSITION, MEETINGS.
   The Commission of Inter-Group Relations shall be comprised of five members
designated by the Mayor from those appointed as provided in Section
161.01, provided that the Secretary of the Board of Community Relations may not
serve.  The Mayor shall convene the Commission originally, and he shall serve
as the Chairman of such Commission.  It shall adopt such rules as it shall deem
expedient for the conduct of its business.  The Commission shall meet not less
than monthly, except during the months of July and August, on such dates as it
shall determine.  Other meetings of the Commission shall be held upon call of
the Chairman, or as may be determined by the Commission.  (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.06  INTER-GROUP RELATIONS COMMISSION; DUTIES.
   The duties of the Commission of Inter-Group Relations shall be:
   (a)   To study the causes in inter-group tensions which may exist, and to
formulate and carry out a comprehensive educational program designed to:
      (1)   Cultivate better relations between racial, national and religious
groups, working towards the elimination and prevention of all undemocratic
barriers that curb equality of rights and opportunities and that produce
prejudice or discrimination based upon race, color, religion, national origin
or ancestry;
      (2)   Help build a community where people will learn increasingly to act
on the basis of the facts and accept or reject a person on the basis of
individual merit, regardless of race, color, religion or national origin.
      (3)   Recognize and emphasize the value of cultural differences and
encourage various cultural groups to share fully in community life;
      (4)   Build a city where all the people will increasingly understand and
appreciate the composite character of the American population.
   (b)   To assemble and analyze factual data concerning racial and religious
discrimination and other related practices in the area of housing,
transportation, education, health service, civil rights, recreation and law and
order;
   (c)   To confer and cooperate with and furnish technical assistance to
employers, labor unions, employment agencies and other public and private
agencies in formulating educational programs for the elimination of prejudice
and discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry
and to stimulate the establishment of committees for this purpose in industry,
labor, civic life and other areas;
   (d)   To make technical studies and prepare and disseminate educational
material relating to discrimination and prejudice, and ways and means of
reducing and eliminating it;
   (e)   To formulate and prepare recommendations for the enactment of such
ordinances and other legislation as they deem necessary.  These recommendations
shall be presented to the Community Relations Board.
   (f)   To report their activities, findings and recommendations to every
meeting of the Community Relations Board or upon request of the Chairman of the
Community Relations Board.
      (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.07  COMMISSION OF EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES; COMPOSITION,  MEETINGS.
   The Commission of Employment Practices shall be comprised of five members
designated by the Mayor from those appointed as provided in Section
161.01, provided that the Secretary of the Community Relations Board may not
serve.  The Mayor shall convene the Commission originally, and he shall serve
as the Chairman of the Commission. It shall adopt such rules as it shall deem
expedient for the conduct of its business.  The Commission shall meet not less
than monthly, except during the months of July and August, on such dates as it
shall determine. Other meetings of the Commission shall be held upon call of
the Chairman, or as may be determined by the Commission.  (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.08  COMMISSION OF EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES; DUTIES.
   The duties of the Commission of Employment Practices shall be:
   (a)   To receive and investigate and seek to adjust all complaints of unfair
employment practices as hereinafter defined, provided that the complaint is
made to the commission within sixty days of such alleged unfair practice.
   (b)   To be the administrative agent charged with the duty of effectuating
the provisions and purposes of this chapter through the Community Relations
Board.
      (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.09  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the
following meanings, unless otherwise indicated:
   (a)   "Discriminate", "discriminated" or "discrimination" means and includes
discrimination solely on the grounds or because of race, religious creed,
color, national origin or ancestry.
   (b)   "Person" means and includes an individual, partnership, corporation,
union or association, including those acting in a fiduciary or representative
capacity, whether appointed by a court or otherwise.  Whenever used in any
clause prescribing  and imposing a penalty, the term "person", as applied to
partnerships, unions or associations, shall mean the partners or members
thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof.  The singular
shall include the plural and the masculine shall include the feminine and
neuter.
   (c)   "Employee" means and includes all persons except those engaged in
domestic service, personal service or an employee of an organized religious
congregation or an employee of an organization or institution limited to
members of a single religious faith.
   (d)   "Employer" means a person, one or more individuals, a partnership,
association or corporation hiring employees unless exemption is provided in
Section
161.11.
   (e)   "Labor organization" means any organization which exists or is
constituted for the purpose, in whole or in part, of collective bargaining or
of dealing with employers concerning grievances, terms or conditions of
employment, or of mutual aid or protection in connection with employment.
   (f)   "Employment agency" means any person, company, partnership,
association or corporation which undertakes, with or without compensation, to
procure, recruit, refer or place employees.
      (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.10  UNFAIR EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES.
   It shall be unlawful for employers, labor unions, employment agencies and
others subject to this chapter to:
   (a)   Discriminate against any person with regard to hire, discharge,
tenure, upgrading terms, or conditions of employment or union membership solely
on the grounds of race, religious creed, color, national origin or ancestry.
   (b)   Publish or cause to be published any notice or advertisement relating
to employment or membership which contains any specification or limitations as
to race, religious creed, color, national origin or ancestry.
   (c)   Require of any applicant as the conditions of employment or
membership, any information concerning his race, religious creed, color,
national origin or ancestry.
   (d)   To fail or refuse to classify properly, refer for employment or
otherwise discriminate against any individual because of his race, color,
religion or national origin or ancestry.
   (e)   To discriminate against any individual or to limit, segregate or
classify its membership in any way which would deprive or tend to deprive such
individual of employment opportunities or would limit his employment
opportunities or otherwise adversely affect his status as an employee or as an
applicant for employment or would adversely affect his wages, hours or
employment conditions, because of such individual's race, religious creed,
color, national origin or ancestry.
   (f)   To penalize or discriminate in any manner against any individual
because he has opposed any practice forbidden by this chapter or because he has
made a charge, testified or assisted in any manner in any investigation,
proceeding or hearing thereunder.
   (g)   Aid, abet, encourage or incite the commission of any discrimination in
employment practice prohibited by this chapter.
   It is specifically provided that if the provisions of this chapter are not
otherwise violated, it shall not be an unfair employment practice for any
employer to select for employment or employ any person who possesses
qualifications, training or experience which best adapts him for the welfare
and interest of such employer's business or profession.
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.11  AUTHORIZED EXEMPTIONS.
   Exemptions from the requirements of this chapter shall be:
   (a)   Any employer of less than twelve persons.  The members of the
immediate family of any employer shall not be included in determining the
number of employees.
   (b)   Any religious organization or institution whose membership or service
is limited to persons of a single faith.
   (c)   Any private organization having a purely social or fraternal purpose.
   (d)   Any type of employment where religion, religious creed or nationality
would usually and normally be considered an essential qualification of
employment.
      (Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.12  INVESTIGATIONS, HEARINGS AND ENFORCEMENT.
   Upon its own initiative or whenever a complaint has been made that a person
has engaged or is engaged in unfair employment practices, the Commission shall
determine the facts and if there appears to be probable cause for the complaint
it shall use its offices to attempt an adjustment by education, persuasion,
reconciliation and conference.
   If, in the opinion of a majority of the members of the Commission the
efforts to settle any complaint by education, persuasion, conciliation and
conference have not adjusted the specific complaint, the Commission shall
report its efforts and findings to the Community Relations Board, which shall
also use its offices to settle the complaint by reconciliation and conference.
   If the complaint is not properly adjusted to the satisfaction of the Board
within thirty days, the Board shall cause a public hearing to be held.  A
notice of the particulars of the complaint shall be sent to the respondent by
registered mail not less than ten days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
The hearing shall be held before the Community Relations Board.  The respondent
shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and appear at such
hearing to testify in his own behalf, or be represented by counsel, or
otherwise and to examine and cross-examine witnesses.  If upon all the
testimony taken, the Board, by a two-thirds vote of the members thereof, shall
determine that the respondent committed the discrimination practice set forth
in the complaint, the Board shall issue an order directing the respondent to
cease such discriminatory employment practice so found to be engaged in.  The
Board shall have power to require proof of compliance.
   In the event the respondent refuses or fails to comply with the order of the
Board, the fact of such refusal together with the verified complaint and the
record of the proceedings of the public hearing shall be certified to the Law
Director for legal proceedings for compliance with this chapter.
   Whenever the Commission finds that any official, agent or employee of this
City, or any contractor or subcontractor doing work for this City, has engaged
in any unfair employment practice, it shall investigate the facts and make a
report thereof to the Community Relations Board.  The Board, by majority vote,
may certify the case to the Mayor for appropriate action.
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.13  OFFICE REQUIREMENTS AND EXPENSES.
   The City shall provide such office space and clerical assistance as Council
may approve upon request to it by the Board.  Other expenses of the Board shall
be met by such appropriations as are made by Council for such purposes.
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.14  LOYALTY OATH.
   Every person who shall seek, under the terms of this chapter, any of the
rights and privileges herein prescribed shall first sign a loyalty that he does
not advocate or has not advocated a change by force or violence in the
constitutional form of the government of the United States, or of this State,
or the overthrow of any government in the United States by force or violence,
or who has been convicted of or is under indictment or information charging any
subversive act within the United States, and shall agree to take an oath in
writing before a person authorized to administer oaths in the State of Ohio,
which oath shall be substantially as follows:
   "I,                  , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support 
and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the
State of Ohio against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true
faith and allegiance to the same and that I take this obligation freely without
any mental reservation or purpose of evasion.
   "And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I a
member of any political party or organization that advocates, the overthrow of
the government of the United States, or of this State, or of this City by force
or violence; and that I do not intend to become a member of any political party
or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State or City by force or violence."
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
161.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned not more than twenty days
if such fine is not paid within thirty days or the execution thereof stayed by
appeal or order of the court.
(Ord. 44, 1963.)
CHAPTER 162
Spring Grove Cemetery Advisory Board
162.01   Established.
162.02   Members.
162.03   Meetings.
162.04   Duties.
 
 
162.01  ESTABLISHED.
   It is hereby determined to be necessary to establish a Spring Grove Cemetery
Advisory Board.  (Ord. 13, 2010.  Passed 3-15-10.)
162.02  MEMBERS.
   (a)   The Board shall consist of three members and one member must have a
family
member buried in the cemetery.
   (b)   The Board members shall be appointed by Council.
   (c)   A member's term on the Board shall be for a period of three (3) years.
It is the desire of Council that the terms be staggered. Therefore, one
member's term shall end on December 31, 2011; one member's term shall end on
December 31, 2012; and, the third member's term shall end on December 31, 2013.
Thereafter, each member of the Board shall serve for a term of three (3)
years.  (Ord. 13, 2010.  Passed 3-15-10.)
162.03  MEETINGS.
   Board meetings shall occur at least on a quarterly basis and more
frequently, if the Board so desires. The Board shall select a chairman and a
secretary who shall keep minutes of the Board meetings. The Board shall be
subject to the "open meetings law".
(Ord. 13, 2010.  Passed 3-15-10.)
162.04  DUTIES.
   The Board shall serve an advisory function to Council and the Service Safety
Director and not by way of limitation make recommendations to Council and the
Service Safety Director as follows:
   (a)   Rules and Regulations of the cemetery.
   (b)   Rates for Opening and Closing graves and monument installation.
   (c)   Rates of pay for services provided to the cemetery.
   (d)   Fund-raising.
   (e)   Organizing volunteers.  (Ord. 13, 2010.  Passed 3-15-10.)
CHAPTER 163
James Godwin Fund Board of Trustees
163.01   Establishment, composition and duties; bond.
 
 
163.01  ESTABLISHMENT, COMPOSITION AND DUTIES; BOND.
   There is hereby established a Board of Trustees, subject to the approval of
the Judge of Probate Court of Columbiana County, to manage and invest the
bequest of the late James Godwin to the worthy poor of the City.
   Such Board of Trustees shall consist of five members to be appointed by
Council, who shall serve without compensation and during good behavior.
   The Board of Trustees shall give bond to the Probate Court in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000) and shall have authority to appoint its President,
Secretary, Treasurer and such other officers as it may deem proper.
   The Board of Trustees shall render a statement to Council annually, and
shall at the same time file an account with the Probate Court of Columbiana
County.
(1967 Code 163.01.)
CHAPTER 165
Thompson Park
165.01   Appointment of Park Commissioners; duties.
165.02   Designation and compensation; power to appoint Superintendent.
165.03   Rules and regulations.
165.04   Superintendent of Thompson Park; duties.
165.05   Prohibited practices.
165.06   Enforcement.
165.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Police and sanitary jurisdiction extended to public parks - see ADM.
145.02
      Board of Park Commissioners - see ADM. Ch.
151
 
 
165.01  APPOINTMENT OF PARK COMMISSIONERS; DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall appoint five persons, subject to the approval of Council,
who shall be known as Park Commissioners, not less than three of whom shall be
residents of the City.  The Park Commissioners shall govern, manage and control
Thompson Park, subject to the provisions of these Codified Ordinances and other
ordinances of the City.  They shall make such improvements and establishments
as they deem proper and expedient.
(Ord. 69, 2004.  Passed 10-18-04.)
165.02  DESIGNATION AND COMPENSATION; POWER TO APPOINT SUPERINTENDENT.
   The Commissioners appointed by the Mayor under the provisions of Section
165.01 shall constitute a board to be known as the Park Commissioners of
Thompson Park, and they shall serve without compensation.  They shall have the
power to appoint a Superintendent and all necessary employees and prescribe
their duties and fix their compensation.  Such compensation shall be subject to
the approval of Council.
(1967 Code 165.02)
165.03  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Park Commissioners shall make such rules and regulations not
inconsistent with these Codified Ordinances and other ordinances of the City
that they may deem necessary for the management and protection of Thompson
Park.
(1967 Code 165.03)
165.04  SUPERINTENDENT OF THOMPSON PARK; DUTIES.
   The position of Superintendent of Thompson Park of the City is hereby
created.  Such position shall be appointed and filled by the Park Commissioners
and the incumbent shall perform such appropriate duties relating to the
position as shall, from time to time, be assigned to him.
(1967 Code 165.04)
165.05  PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
   The following regulations shall govern the conduct of persons using the
Thompson Park area:
   (a)   Carrying Away Sod, Wildlife, Etc.  No person shall take or carry away
from the Park any sod, clay, turf, stone, gravel, leaves, peat, wood, plants,
flowers, wildlife or anything of like kind.
   (b)   Discharge of Fireworks or Firearms; Throwing Stones.  No person shall
discharge firearms, fireworks or any other explosive device within the
boundaries of the Park; and no one shall throw stones or other missiles within,
from or onto the Park premises.
   (c)   Fires.  No person, other than Park employees, shall light, make or use
any open fire or combustible substance within the Park without first obtaining
the approval and consent of the Park Superintendent.
   (d)   Sales; Signs; Handbills.  No person shall solicit, sell or expose
anything for sale within the Park, nor post or attach any bill, notice, paper
or like sign within the Park or upon any Park property, without first obtaining
permission from the Park Board; nor, shall there be permitted by any means, the
distribution of any handbill, circular, card or other like notice within the
Park without first obtaining permission of the Park Board.
   (e)   Golfballs, Arrows, Model Planes, Etc.  No person shall drive
golfballs, use a bow and arrow, or fly model airplanes or rockets on Park
property, except in those areas designated for such use and posted by the Park
Board.
   (f)   Speed Limits.  No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the Park
at a speed in excess of fifteen miles per hour.  (Ord. 40, 1978.)
   (g)   Non-licensed Motorcycles, Etc.  No person shall operate a non-licensed
or otherwise non-street legal motorcycle, mini-bike, moped, trail bike, go-cart
or snowmobile upon park property, including improved roads and unimproved
trails and paths.  Licensed motorcycles that are legal to operate upon any
public road are not prohibited from being operated within the park upon
improved roads.
      (Ord. 70, 2003.  Passed 12-1-03.)
   (h)   Motor Vehicle Washing or Repair.  No person shall use water taken from
a Park water spigot or natural spring to wash any motor vehicle, nor shall any
person repair a motor vehicle upon Park property.
      (Ord. 40, 1978.)
   (i)   Loud Music.  No person shall play or operate any radio, phonograph,
tape player or electronically amplified musical instrument or device in a loud
or unreasonable manner in any area within the Park.
      (Ord. 26, 1982.)
165.06  ENFORCEMENT.
   No person shall fail to comply with any lawful order of the Thompson Park
Superintendent or any of his agents, or any law enforcement officer in the
administration and enforcement of any of the Park rules and regulations
contained in this chapter; or of any City ordinances or State law applicable to
the protection of the health, safety, welfare and peaceable enjoyment of the
Park by the public and the preservation of Park property.
(Ord. 40, 1978.)
165.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of Section
165.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates any provision of Section
165.06 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 40, 1978.)
CHAPTER 166
The Riverfest Commission
166.01   Establishment; membership.
166.02   Duties and powers.
 
 
166.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby established a Riverfest Commission consisting of an
unlimited number of members.  The members of such Commission shall serve
without compensation and shall be appointed by the Mayor for terms to be
specified by the Mayor.
(Ord. 39, 1992.  Passed 7-6-92.)
166.02  DUTIES AND POWERS.
   The duty of the Riverfest Commission shall be to organize, develop, promote
and administrate the annual East Liverpool Riverfest.  The Commission shall
also have such powers and duties as are conferred and authorized from time to
time by Council.
(Ord. 39, 1992.  Passed 7-6-92.)
CHAPTER 167
Board of Control
167.01   Board of Control.
167.02   Approval of contracts.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      See sectional histories for similar State law
      Deposit of public moneys - see Ohio R.C. 117.17
      Fines and fees collected by Mayor - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
      Establishment of required funds - see Ohio R.C. 5705.09
      Special funds authorized - see Ohio R.C. 5705.12
 
 
167.01  BOARD OF CONTROL.
   The Mayor and the Director of Public Service-Safety shall constitute the
Board of Control.  The Mayor shall be President, ex officio, of the Board of
Control.  The Board of Control shall keep a record of its proceedings.  All
votes shall be by "yeas" and "nays" and be entered on the record of its
proceedings.  The vote of the majority of all the members of the Board of
Control shall be necessary to adopt any question, motion or order.  The Board
of Control shall have all the powers and perform all the duties imposed upon
such Board by the laws of the State.
(ORC 733.21)
167.02  APPROVAL OF CONTRACTS.
   No contract in the Department of Public Service-Safety, in excess of the
amount specified in Ohio R.C. 733.22 shall be awarded except on the approval of
the Board of Control, which Board shall direct the Director of the Department
of Public Service-Safety to enter into the contract.  The members of the Board
shall prepare estimates of the revenue and expenditures of the Department to be
submitted to Council by the Mayor, as provided by law.
(ORC 733.22)
CHAPTER 168
City Tourism Bureau
168.01   Establishment.
168.02   Membership; term.
168.03   Duties.
168.04   Meetings.
168.05   Contributions.
168.06   Liaison.
 
 
168.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby created a City Tourism Bureau (hereinafter the City
Bureau).  The purpose of the City Bureau shall be to attract tourists and
visitors to the City and surrounding area, and for management and expenditure
of funds received by the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5739.09 pertaining to
contributions to a convention and tourism bureau operating within Columbiana
County.  (Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
168.02  MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   (a)   Membership.  The City Bureau shall be composed of five members.  One
member shall be an East Liverpool Councilperson, one member shall be a
representative of any East Liverpool City Lodging facility; and the remaining
three members shall be electors of the City.  The Mayor shall appoint all
members with the consent of Council.  All members shall serve without pay.
   (b)   Term.  The term of each member shall be as follows:
      (1)   The initial terms of the member representing City Council and the
member representing an East Liverpool City lodging facility shall expire on
December 31, 2006.  Thereafter, the term shall be for two years.
      (2)   The initial terms for the three members representing electors of
the City shall expire on December 31, 2007.  Thereafter, the terms shall be for
two years.  (Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
168.03  DUTIES.
   (a)   The City Bureau shall initiate, promote and support events that will
develop cultural interest and tourist attractions in the City and surrounding
areas.  The Commission may, in carrying out these duties, enter into joint
ventures and/or partnerships with private tourist promoting organizations or
other convention and tourism bureaus.
   (b)   The City Bureau shall create a competitive process for distribution of
funds received by the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5739.09 and earmarked for
private tourism promoting organizations or other convention and visitors
bureaus operating within Columbiana County; and shall regulate the distribution
of said funds to maximize its fullest promotional potential while minimizing
overhead/administrative costs.
   (c)   The City Bureau shall also have the authority to adopt rules and
regulations for its operation. 
(Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
168.04  MEETINGS.
   The City Bureau shall meet as necessary, but at least every three months,
and have special meetings upon call of the chairman or any two members of the
Bureau.  All meetings are open to the public and shall comply with Ohio’s “open
meeting” laws.
(Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
168.05  CONTRIBUTIONS.
   The City Bureau and any private tourist promoting organization or other
convention and visitors bureau receiving contributions from the City pursuant
to Ohio R.C. 5739.09(B)(1) shall receive said contributions subject to the
following guidelines:
   (a)   No more than twenty percent (20%) of any contribution shall be used
for administrative expenses.
   (b)   Fifteen percent (15%) of the contributions used for advertising may be
reserved to advertising within the City and the remainder shall be used for
advertising outside of the immediate area.
   (c)   A budget shall be developed, submitted and approved by the East
Liverpool City Council Tourism Committee and any modifications thereto shall
require further approval by said Committee.
   (d)   Any entity receiving contributions from the City shall hold four
public meetings, one each quarter and issue contemporaneously a written
financial report on the use of contributions to the East Liverpool City Council
Tourism Committee.
      (Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
168.06  LIAISON.
   The East Liverpool City Treasurer shall be the liaison between the Tourism
Bureau and the City and shall have a representative attend each meeting of the
Tourism Bureau.  The Treasurer shall also be the authorized person to sign
purchase orders as directed by the Bureau.
(Ord. 43, 2006.  Passed 7-19-06.)
CHAPTER 169
Records Commission
169.01   Creation; members; meetings.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Records commission - see Ohio R.C. 149.39
Open meetings - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
 
 
169.01  CREATION; MEMBERS; MEETINGS.
   (a)   There is hereby created a Records Commission for the City of East
Liverpool composed of the Mayor, who shall be chairman, the Auditor, the Law
Director and a citizen appointed by the Mayor.
   (b)   The Commission shall appoint a secretary, who may or may not be a
member of the Commission and who shall serve at the pleasure of the Commission.
   (c)   The Commission shall meet at least once every six months and upon call
of the chairman.  (Res. 12, 1994.  Passed 10-3-94.)

Officers and Employees Generally
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  Compensatory and fringe benefits provisions are no longer

171.01  APPOINTMENT OF MUNICIPAL OFFICERS.
   The Director of Public Service-Safety, or any board or officer whose
appointment is required by this Administrative Code, shall be appointed not
earlier than the second Monday in January and not later than the first Monday
in February, and shall hold their respective offices until their successors are
appointed as herein required.
(ORC 733.04)
171.02  SALARIES AND WAGES.
   Except as otherwise provided by law, the salaries of all officials of the
City shall be fixed from time to time by Council, and the wages of all other
employees shall be fixed in such manner as Council shall determine, and until
so fixed all salaries and wages shall remain as now established.
(ORC 731.08)
   The salary of any officer, clerk or employee shall not be increased or
diminished during the term for which he was elected or appointed.  This section
does not prohibit  the payment of any increased costs of continuing to provide
the identical benefits provided to an officer at the commencement of his term
of office.  Except as otherwise provided by law, all fees pertaining to any
office shall be paid into the City Treasury.
(ORC 731.07.)
171.03  QUALIFICATIONS; OATHS.
   Each officer of the City, or of any department or board thereof, whether
elected or appointed as a substitute for a regular officer, shall be an elector
of the City, except as otherwise expressly provided, and before entering upon
his official duties shall tax an oath to support the Constitution of the United
States and the Constitution of Ohio, and an oath that he will faithfully,
honestly and impartially discharge the duties of his office.  Such provisions
as to official oaths shall extend to deputies, but they need not be electors.
(ORC 733.68)
171.04  OFFICIAL BONDS; PREPARATION AND APPROVAL.
   The official bonds of all municipal officers shall be prepared or approved
by the Law Director.  They shall be in such sum as Council prescribes by
general or special ordinance and be subject to the approval of the Mayor,
except that the Mayor's bond shall be approved by Council, or if it is not
legally organized, by the Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas of Columbiana
County.
(ORC 733.70)
171.05  RECORDING OF BONDS.
   Each officer required by law or ordinance to give bond shall do so before
entering upon the duties of his office, except those covered under the public
employees' blanket bond and except as otherwise provided by law.  In its
discretion, Council at any time may require each officer to give a new or
additional bond.  Except that of the City Auditor, each bond, upon its
approval, shall be delivered to the City Auditor, who shall immediately record
it in a record provided for that purpose and file and carefully preserve it in
his office.  The bond of the City Auditor shall be delivered to the City
Treasurer who shall in like manner record and preserve it.
(Ord. 19, 1969.)
171.06  AMOUNT OF BONDS.
   The respective officers and employees of the City shall furnish bond to the
City for the faithful performance of the duties of their respective offices or
appointments in the amounts as follows:
 
Mayor                            $ 2,000.00
Auditor                            1,000.00
Law Director                       1,000.00
Treasurer                          20,000.00
Income Tax Department Supervisor   10,000.00
Income Tax Department - Clerks     10,000.00
 
(Ord. 19, 1969.)
171.07  PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' BLANKET BOND.
   All other officials and employees of the City, not enumerated under Section
171.06 and those under the control and supervision of the Board of Public
Utilities, shall be covered under the provisions of the public employees'
blanket bond in lieu of the execution of individual bonds.  The public
employees' blanket bond shall be in the amount of two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500) for each of the aforementioned covered individuals; except for
the Director of Public Service-Safety and the Municipal Court Clerk who shall
be bonded in the amount of six thousand dollars ($6,000) and except for the
parking meter repairman, Incinerator Department Superintendent, Municipal Court
Bailiff and Municipal Court deputy clerks, who shall be bonded in the amount of
five thousand dollars ($5,000) each.
(Ord. 19, 1969.)
171.08  BOND COVERAGE.
   The public employees' blanket bond provided in Section
171.07 shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties and
offices of the individual covered officials and employees and upon the
accounting for and paying over to the proper official of the City all moneys
and other property coming into possession of such individual.
(Ord. 19, 1969.)
171.09  REMOVAL OF CITY OFFICERS.
   When the Mayor or any elector has reason to believe that the head of a
department or any officer has been guilty in the performance of his official
duty of bribery, misfeasance, malfeasance, nonfeasance, misconduct in
office,gross neglect of duty, gross immorality or habitual drunkenness, he
shall immediately file with Council, except when the removal of such head of
department or officer is otherwise provided for, written charges against such
person, setting forth in detail a statement of such alleged guilt, and, at the
same time, or as soon thereafter as possible, serve or cause to be served a
true copy of such charges with  the person against whom the charges are made. 
Such service may be in person or by leaving a copy of the charges at the office
of such person, and due return thereof made to Council, as is provided for the
return of the service of summons in a civil action.  The proceedings governing
the actions of Council shall be such as are set out in Ohio R.C. 733.36 et seq.
(ORC 733.35)
171.10  ARMED SERVICES DEFINED.
   As used in Sections
171.11 to
171.13 "armed services of the United States" means Air Force, Army, Navy,
Marine Corps, Coast Guard, Auxiliary Corps as established by Congress, Army
Nurse Corps, Navy Nurse Corps, Red Cross Nurse serving in the Army, Navy or
Hospital Service of the United States, and such other service as may be
designated by the Congress of the United States as included therein.
(1967 Code 171.08)
171.11  CITY EMPLOYEES ENTERING ARMED SERVICES.
   Any person who has been employed by the City for a period of ninety days or
more and who enlists, is commissioned or is called into the armed forces of the
United States as a result of any act of Congress, action of the President of
the United States or his status in any reserve force, national guard or other
similar organization may, upon his release, make application for restoration to
his former office or position. Such application shall be made within ninety
days after receipt of an honorable discharge, certificate or other evidence
showing satisfactory completion of his period of service.  Within thirty days
after making such application the applicant shall be restored to the office or
position held by him immediately prior to his entry into the armed services of
the United States provided such person is at such time physically able to
perform the duties of his office or position.
(1967 Code 171.09)
171.12  PERIOD OF SERVICE AS CREDIT TO STATUS WITH CITY.
   Whenever the time or period of employment in the classified service affects
the status, rank, rating or qualifications in any respect of any person who has
served in the armed services of the United States, such person shall be given
credit for the period in which he served in the armed services as though such
time were served in the course of his regular employment.
(1967 Code 171.10)
171.13  PERSONS APPOINTED TO FILL VACANCIES OF SERVICE  PERSONNEL.
   The provisions of Sections
171.10 to
171.12 shall not be applicable nor shall the benefits thereof be extended to
any person appointed to a position to fill a vacancy created by reason of the
entering of the former incumbent of any office or position into the armed
services of the United States.
(1967 Code 171.11)
171.14  RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT: NONCLASSIFIED EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   All non-classified employees of the City, now in the employ of, or
hereafter to be employed by the City, are hereby required as a condition of
their continued employment to have their place of abode within the East
Liverpool City School District, and to be bona fide residents therein, except
as provided hereafter.
   (b)   A “bona fide resident”, for purposes of this section, means a person
having a permanent domicile within the East Liverpool City School District, as
determined by the tax district number assigned to the permanent parcel by the
Columbiana County Auditor and Treasurer, and one which has not been adopted
with the intention of again taking up or claiming a previous acquired residence
outside of the District, with the following exceptions:
      (1)   Employees hired before April 2, 1990 who currently reside outside
of the District may continue to reside at their present residence, although any
future move to a new residence shall be within the District.
      (2)   All new non-classified employees shall have twelve months to become
residents of the District.
      (3)   Waiver of residence.  For positions requiring peculiar and
exceptional qualification of a scientific, managerial, professional or
educational character, or because of difficulty in securing qualified
applicants who are residents of the East Liverpool City School District,
residence may be waived upon approval of Council by resolution.
   (c)   Failure of any non-classified employee to comply with the residence
requirements provided herein shall be cause for removal or discharge from the
City service.
(Ord.  47, 2000.  Passed 7-3-00.)
171.15  RESIDENCY  REQUIREMENT:  CLASSIFIED EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   All classified employees of the City hired before June 4, 1990, are
hereby required to meet any residency requirements that may have been in effect
at the time of their hire.
   (b)   All classified employees of the City hired on or after June 4, 1990
are hereby required as a condition of their continued employment to have their
place of abode within the East Liverpool City School District, and to be bona
fide residents therein, except as provided hereafter.
   (c)   A “bona fide resident”, for purposes of this section, means a person
having a permanent domicile within the East Liverpool City School District, as
determined by the tax district number assigned to the permanent parcel by the
Columbiana County Auditor and Treasurer, and one which has not been adopted
with the intention of again taking up or claiming a previous acquired residence
outside of the District, with the following exceptions:
      (1)   All new classified employees shall have twelve months to become
residents of the District.
      (2)   Waiver of residence.  For positions requiring peculiar and
exceptional qualification of a scientific, managerial, professional or
educational character, or because of difficulty in securing qualified
applicants who are residents of the East Liverpool City School District,
residence may be waived upon approval of Council by resolution.
   (d)   Failure of any classified employee to comply with the residence
requirements provided herein shall be cause for removal or discharge from the
City service.
(Ord.  48, 2000.  Passed 7-3-00.)
171.16  CREDIT CARD POLICY.
   (a)   Eligibility.  The Mayor, Safety Service Director or designee (Mayor/
designee) shall identify those employees whose day-to-day responsibilities
require access to a City credit card.  In addition, the Mayor/designee shall
determine the appropriate credit limit for those individuals/cards.
   Before receiving a City credit card, authorized employees must complete an
acknowledgement of receipt of this policy.
   (b)   Policy.  The City credit card is issued solely for the purpose of
conducting City business and is not to be used for any personal expenses. 
Personal and/or unauthorized usage of a City credit card may be immediate
grounds for revocation of the credit card and disciplinary action up to and
including termination of employment.  Reimbursement to the City for any
outstanding unauthorized charges may be recovered through payroll deduction and
such other means as may be necessary.  The use of a City credit card to
purchase goods or services does not waive any City purchasing procedures. 
Pursuant to the Ohio State Auditor’s Office, employees are prohibited from
taking personal advantage of frequent flier miles or credit card points when
utilizing a City credit card for City business.
   The City recognizes that the credit card provides convenience to employees
in acquiring goods and services for the City.  The City also recognize the risk
inherent with credit card usage.  Therefore, whenever a vendor will accept a
City purchase order, a purchase order should be used in lieu of the City credit
card.
   For individual expenditures, the expense must fall within pre-approved
budgets, and an approved expense appropriation request form must be submitted
to the Mayor/designee prior to incurring the expense.  Signed receipts must be
turned in to the Department Head within two (2) business days.  If an employee
is out of town during the expenditure, signed receipts should be turned in
within two (2) business days of returning the work.
   Employees must surrender all City credit cards upon their separation of
employment from the City or when requested by the Mayor/designee.
   In the event the card is lost or stolen, the cardholder must immediately
notify the Mayor/designee as soon as reasonably possible.  The employee is to
assist the Mayor/designee in identifying and resolving any charges made to the
account.
(Ord. 2, 2016.  Passed 1-19-16.)
171.17  SOCIAL MEDIA/NETWORKING POLICY.
   (a)   Purpose.  The purpose of this policy is to make an employee aware of
his or her privacy rights and prohibited conduct with respect to an employee’s
actions and its impact on the City.  Moreover, this policy is intended to
ensure efficient use of employee time and to minimize any distraction from any
employee’s assigned tasks and duties.
   (b)   Scope.  All employees will be subject to and held accountable for any
conduct outlined in this Social Networking Policy.
   (c)   Consent.  An employee’s use of social media and/or networking
technology constitutes consent to being monitored by the City.
   (d)   Social Networking refers to the use of websites such as, but not
limited to, Facebook, Myspace, Twitter, LinkedIn (cyberspace).  For purposes of
this policy, blogs and other internet forums of communication are included. 
Employees shall not post any pictures in uniform or of any City buildings,
vehicles, or anything representing City/departmental employment without prior
approval of the Department Head and/or Service-Safety Director.
   (e)   Policy. 
      (1)   On Duty Conduct:  While at work, an employee may only access social
networking websites, Blogs and/or other internet forums of communication as an
investigatory tool within the scope of job duties.  This includes access from a
personal cellular device (e.g., Blackberry device, iPhone, other smartphone,
etc.) during an employee’s hours of work.  Employees found to have violated
this policy may be subject to discipline up to and including termination. 
Nothing in this policy is meant to prohibit access to any website or blog which
may be work related.
      (2)   Off Duty Conduct:  An employee enjoys no expectation of privacy to
information posted into cyberspace even while off duty.  This includes anything
posted to a social networking website, Blog, or other similar internet forum of
communication.  although information may be posted to a “private” webpage, the
employee should be aware this information can still be accessed by the public
and other sources in a number of ways.  Because of this, an employee needs to
use “common-sense” and good judgment when posting comments, photos, opinions,
or any other information.  By no means is this policy meant to infringe upon an
individual’s First Amendment rights.  However, anything that reflects
negatively on the Employer, or its mission, may be used as grounds for
discipline up to and including termination.  Unacceptable conduct includes but
is not limited to:
         A.   Posting pictures, videos, or comments that are insubordinate with
respect to the employee’s employment.
         B.   Posting pictures,  videos, or comments (via social media or
email) that constitute or could be construed as immoral or unlawful behavior,
or as obscene, vulgar, lewd, or discriminatory in nature.
         C.   Knowingly or recklessly posting false information about the
Employer, supervisors, coworkers, public officials, or those who have a
relationship with the Employer. This also includes disparagement of a
fictitious character or computer-generated likeness that resembles the above.
         D.   Posting, transmitting, or disseminating any pictures or videos of
official training, activities, or work-related assignments without the express
permission of the Department Head and/or Service-Safety Director.  This
includes posting pictures or video in uniform and/or of City vehicles,
equipment, buildings, or anything representative of the City without prior
approval as set forth in subsection (d) hereof.
         E.   Posting pictures, videos, or comments that are sexual, violent,
offensive, harassing, or pornographic in nature along with any reference to the
Employer or individual’s employment.
   (f)   Employees shall not imply they are speaking on behalf of the Employer
(City or Department).
   (g)   Confidential Information.  An employee shall not disclose any work-
related confidential or proprietary information on any social networking
website, blog, or other internet forum of communication.  This can include
information that may eventually be obtained through a valid public record’s
request.
   (h)   Employee’s found to have violated any part of this policy may be
subject to discipline up to and including termination.
   (i)   Any deviation from the above policy shall require express approval by
the Employer.
   (j)   Any questions regarding the policy should be directed to the
employee’s Department Head or Service-Safety Director.
   (k)   Employees shall not operate or maintain a website that creates the
appearance of being an official representation of the City’s business. 
Exceptions must have the prior written approval of the Mayor.  (Ord. 68, 2015. 
Passed 12-21-15.)
TITLE SEVEN - Taxation

CHAPTER 181
Transient Occupancy Tax

181.02   Imposition of tax.
181.021   Supplemental tax.
