same and responsible therefore, shall distribute such receipts in return for
donations.
(Ord. 49, 1990.  Passed 8-6-90.)
715.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third
degree, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 49, 1990.  Passed 8-6-90.)
CHAPTER 721
Traveling Public Shows or Carnivals
721.01   Permit required; fee and application.
721.02   Permit issuance.
721.03   Refund of deposit moneys.
721.04   Intoxicating liquor on premises.
721.05   Enforcement.
721.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Animals running at large - see GEN. OFF.
 505.01
      Disorderly conduct and peace disturbance - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
509
      Littering and deposit of garbage, rubbish, junk, etc. - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Noxious or offensive odors from places where animals are kept, fed - see
GEN. OFF. Ch.
521
      Possession or consumption of intoxicating beverage in public places - see
GEN. OFF. Ch.
529
      Destruction of property - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
541
 
 
721.01  PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE AND APPLICATION.
   No person shall rent or license to any individual or any group of
individuals, or permit to be used by any individual or group of individuals any
hall, building, room, yard, lot or grove to be used by any proprietor or his
agent, of a traveling public show or carnival in the City until such person
files with the Mayor a written or printed application at least thirty days
prior to the event setting forth the full name of the sponsoring organization
and the name of a responsible individual who will be available twenty-four
hours a day during the time that the traveling public show or carnival is
operating or is physically present within the municipal boundaries of the
City.  The applicant shall pay to the City one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be
deposited in the General Fund, before the permit is issued, and shall also
deposit with the City an additional five hundred dollars ($500.00) to cover any
cost for services rendered by any department of the City.
721.02  PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   No permit shall be issued until the applicant has:
   (a)   Made the deposit and completed the application for the permit referred
to in Section
721.01 .  The permit shall state the exact time when the traveling public show
or carnival will remain in the City, a complete list of all traveling public
show or carnival employees, their home addresses, next of kin, and such further
information as the Mayor may
require, and recent areas where the traveling public show or carnival has
operated and a list of the next three places of operation the traveling public
show or carnival will be performing after leaving the City; and
   (b)   Deposited, to protect the City from any and all lawsuits filed against
it, a policy or policies of liability or indemnity insurance issued by a
company licensed to do business within the State of Ohio, recognizing the City
as an additional insured, in a total amount of not less than one hundred
thousand dollars/three hundred thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000) for any
personal injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) property damage
caused as a result or consequence of the traveling public show or carnival
having appeared within the City.
   (c)   The sponsoring organization shall arrange for traveling public show or
carnival employees to have living quarters outside of any public park area or
other public places, so that the Mayor can be assured that no traveling public
show or carnival employee will be living in trailers or any other type of
living quarters within the traveling public show or carnival area, public parks
or any other public places, except that employees who are responsible for the
safety and/or security of equipment or the grounds may utilize on-premises
camper living quarters, upon securing the prior written approval of the Mayor. 
In addition, no pets belonging to employees of the traveling public show or
carnival will be permitted within the public areas, except such animals as
might be an integral part of the traveling public show or carnival.
721.03  REFUND OF DEPOSIT MONEYS.
   When such traveling public show or carnival has completed its performance
and is about to depart from the City, the Mayor shall ascertain all costs
incurred by the City as a result of the traveling public show or carnival
appearing within the City and shall so advise the auditor of the costs so
incurred, who shall then deduct from the aforesaid five hundred dollars
($500.00) deposit the cost so incurred, and who shall then refund to the person
who made the original deposit, the balance of the deposit remaining.
721.04  INTOXICATING LIQUOR ON PREMISES.
   No intoxicating liquor shall be sold on the premises rented or used as
herein mentioned unless such premises hold proper permits from the Ohio
Department of Liquor Control to dispense intoxicants.  The owner of any
premises rented or used as specified in this chapter shall not allow the use or
consumption of intoxicants or alcoholic beverages on such premises by persons
under the minimum age established by State law.  Notwithstanding the foregoing,
no alcoholic beverages shall be sold and/or consumed by any person upon City-
owned property.
721.05  ENFORCEMENT.
   Properly appointed inspectors and police officers are authorized to inspect
and police any premises used in the manner set forth in this chapter, for the
purpose of maintaining order, preserving peace and the enforcement of law.
721.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.  Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on
each successive day continued.
CHAPTER 737
Junk Dealers
737.01   Definitions.
737.02   License required; application.
737.03   Fee.
737.04   Transferability; revocation.
737.05   Pledges and pawns.
737.06   Business hours.
737.07   Dealing with minors and undesirable persons; identification of
merchandise.
737.08   Business sign; contents.
737.09   Record of purchases and exchanges.
737.10   Retention and identification of purchases and exchanges.
737.11   Exception.
737.12   Enclosures for junk yards and shops.
737.13   Cleanliness of junk yards and shops.
737.14   Inspection.
737.15   Burning junk.
737.16   Storage of junk.
737.17   Dismantling old automobiles.
737.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Receipt of stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
      Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
      Record of transactions - see Ohio R.C. 4737.01, 4737.04
      Pawnbroker - see BUS. REG. Ch.
745
 
 
737.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the following
respective meanings:
   (a)   "Person" means a firm, corporation or individual.
   (b)   "Junk" means any personal property which is or may be salvaged for re-
use, resale, reduction or similar disposition, or which is possessed,
transported, pawned, collected, accumulated, dismantled or assorted for any of
the aforesaid purposes.
Used household furniture, used wearing apparel, used lumber, used brick, used
tile, used plumbing fixtures, used electrical fixtures, used articles made of
precious metal, used jewelry, used tools and other used articles of personal
property, which are bought and sold as secondhand property and which are not
handled as what is ordinarily called junk or salvaged material, shall not be
included in the term junk as used herein.
Without limiting the aforesaid definition of junk, the term shall include used
or salvaged iron, brass, lead, copper and other base metals and their compounds
or combinations, used or salvaged rope, bags, paper, rags, glass, rubber and
similar articles, or property, and used motor vehicles which are used, owned or
possessed for the purpose of wrecking or salvaging parts therefrom.
   (c)   "Junk dealer" means every person who buys, exchanges, collects,
receives or sells any articles herein defined as junk.
   (d)   "Junk yard" or "junk shop" means any place at which a junk dealer
buys, exchanges, collects, receives, stores, accumulates, sells or otherwise
handles junk.
   (e)   "Junk collector" means every junk dealer who does not maintain or
conduct a junk yard or junk shop, but who in his own behalf buys, sells,
exchanges or handles junk and uses, in connection with such business, a motor
vehicle, a horse-drawn vehicle or a pushcart.
      (Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person shall maintain or operate a junk shop or junk yard or engage in
the business of junk collector without first having obtained a license
therefor.  Application for any of the above licenses shall be made to the Mayor
upon such blanks as shall be prescribed by the Mayor.  In making such
application, the applicant shall state his name, whether a person, firm or
corporation, the place at which such business is to be conducted or maintained
and further information as may be required by the Mayor.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.03  FEE.
   With the aforesaid application, the applicant shall pay the following as the
annual license fee for the fiscal year ending December 31 of each year.  The
annual license fee for a junk dealer shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall
be required for each place at which the applicant maintains a junk yard or junk
shop.  The annual license fee for a junk collector shall be twelve dollars and
fifty cents ($12.50) per year.  Such license fees shall not be prorated.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.04  TRANSFERABILITY; REVOCATION.
   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be void if
transferred, and shall be subject to revocation by the Mayor for violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter, or of the laws of the State, or of the
Federal laws, or if in the judgment of the Mayor such revocation is necessary
for the preservation of the public peace, health, safety or welfare.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.05  PLEDGES AND PAWNS.
   No person, or his agent, employee or servant engaged in such businesses, as
defined in Section
737.01, shall receive in the line of such business any article by way of pledge
or pawn, nor shall they loan or advance any sum of money on the security of any
article or thing.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.06  BUSINESS HOURS.
   No person licensed under the provisions of this chapter, or his agent,
servant or employee, shall directly or indirectly purchase or receive by way of
barter or exchange, or otherwise, any articles from any person whatever between
the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.07  DEALING WITH MINORS AND UNDESIRABLE PERSONS; IDENTIFICATION OF
MERCHANDISE.
   No person licensed under the provisions of this chapter, or his agent,
servant or employee, shall directly or indirectly purchase or receive by way of
barter or exchange or otherwise, any of the articles of any minor or
apprentice.
   No person licensed under the provisions of this chapter, or his agent,
servant or employee, shall purchase anything whatsoever from any person who is
at the time intoxicated, from an habitual drunkard, or from any person known to
them to be a thief, or an associate of thieves, or a receiver of stolen
property, or from any person they have reason to suspect as being such.  Nor
shall any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter, or his agent,
servant or employee, purchase or receive any mechanic's tool, instrument or
device having upon it any initials or insignia of ownership, unless the person
offering to give or sell the same shall furnish complete identification of
ownership.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.08  BUSINESS SIGN; CONTENTS.
   Every person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall put in a
conspicuous place in or upon his shop, store, boat or other place of business,
a sign having his name and occupation legibly inscribed thereon.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.09  RECORD OF PURCHASES AND EXCHANGES.
   Every person licensed under the provision of this chapter shall keep a
separate book open to inspection by any member of the Police Department, or to
any other person, in which shall be written in the English language at the time
of every purchase or exchange of any of the articles described in Section
737.01, a full and complete description thereof, the name, description and
residence of the person from whom purchased and received, and the day and hour
when such purchases or exchanges were made.  Each entry shall be numbered
consecutively commencing with number one.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.10  RETENTION AND IDENTIFICATION OF PURCHASES AND EXCHANGES.
   Any and all articles, excepting motor vehicles, described in Section
737.01 purchased or exchanged shall be retained by the purchaser thereof for at
least thirty days before disposing of the same, and shall be kept in an
accessible place in the building where such articles are purchased or received
with a tag attached to such articles in some visible and convenient place with
the number written thereon corresponding to the entry number on the book
required to be kept by Section
737.09.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.11  EXCEPTION.
   In case such purchaser or receiver by exchange or otherwise, as described in
this chapter, is a peddler, or goes about with a wagon to purchase or obtain by
exchange or otherwise, any of the articles not excepted, and does not have a
place of business in any building, he need not hold such articles for thirty
days before selling the same but may sell at any time, provided he shall on
Monday of each week file with the Chief of Police a copy of the record required
by Section
737.09 to be kept in a separate book, of the articles purchased or received
during the preceding week, including such full description of all articles
sold, to whom sold and his place of residence.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.12  ENCLOSURES FOR JUNK YARDS AND SHOPS.
   No person shall maintain a junk yard or junk shop in the City unless such
business is carried on entirely inside a building, or unless the premises on
which such business is carried on are entirely enclosed by a substantially
built fence at least seven feet in height.  Such fence and its construction for
the purpose intended must meet with the approval of the Director of Public
Service-Safety.  Such fence shall be maintained in a neat, safe condition and
shall be painted.  Gates for access to the premises shall swing inwardly and
such gates shall be closed when the premises are not open for business.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.13  CLEANLINESS OF JUNK YARDS AND SHOPS.
   All premises used as a junk yard or junk shop shall be kept and maintained
in as clean, sanitary and neat a condition as such business will reasonably
permit.  The person operating a junk yard or junk shop shall maintain the
premises so used so that rats, vermin and fire hazards are as far as
practicable reduced to a minimum.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.14  INSPECTION.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall inspect or cause to be inspected at
least once every four months all junk yards and junk shops in the City.  Such
inspection shall be for the purpose of seeing that such premises are operated
in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances
applicable, and that they are kept in safe, sanitary condition.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.15  BURNING JUNK.
   No rubbish or portion or parts of wrecked machines and other accumulations
which are to be discarded by such junk dealer shall be burned on such premises
without the written consent of the Chief of the Fire Department.
   No fire disposing of material accumulated in the yard shall be created less
than thirty feet from any building.  Where the yard in which such junk business
is conducted is so small as to not permit compliance with this restriction,
such person so operating such yard is required to build an incinerator within
which the fires may be started to dispose of such refuse or other material
desired to be destroyed by fire, or cleaned in such manner of grease and other
collections.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.16  STORAGE OF JUNK.
   No junk shall be stored in the City unless the same is in a building or
enclosed yard.  Such junk so stored, whether inside of a building or an
enclosed yard, shall be so piled or placed that adequate passageways are open. 
Junk piled in an enclosed yard shall not be piled closer than five feet distant
from the fence enclosing the yard.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.17  DISMANTLING OLD AUTOMOBILES.
   No junk dealer, a part of whose business is that of disposing of old,
obsolete or wrecked automobiles and dismantling same, shall perform any of such
work in the streets or upon sidewalks adjoining his yard, or permit or cause to
be placed upon sidewalks or streets adjacent to the property used by him as a
junk yard any oil, grease or other like material from the automobiles, or parts
thereof, making dangerous the use of same by the citizens, and no automobiles
shall be piled one upon the other in the yard to a height greater than the
nearest fence, nor shall the chassis or other parts of the dismantled cars be
piled in a manner adjacent to the street line liable to cause injury or damage
in the use of the street or sidewalk, as a result of junk so piled, by slipping
or falling into the fence or upon the sidewalk or street.
(Ord. 6, 1959.)
737.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of Sections
737.02 to
737.04 and
737.12 to
737.17 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for the first offense and a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree for each subsequent offense.  Each day of operation
without a license shall be construed as a separate offense.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates any provision of Sections
737.05 to
737.11 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
CHAPTER 745
Pawnbrokers
745.01   Definitions.
745.02   License required; application.
745.03   Records of transactions; contents and inspection.
745.04   Submission of daily report to police.
745.05   Pawnbroker to retain goods for 72 hours; allegedly stolen goods.
745.06   Pledge from minors or intoxicated persons.
745.07   Pawning mechanics' tools; proof of ownership.
745.08   Revocation of license.
745.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R. C. 715.61
      Receipt of stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
537.16
      Pawnbrokers generally - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4727
      Junk dealers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
737
 
 
745.01  DEFINITIONS.
   "Pawnbroker," as used in this chapter, means any person engaged in the
business of lending money on deposit or pledges of personal property or other
valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidences of indebtedness, or
in the business of purchasing personal property, or choses in action, or other
valuable thing, and selling or agreeing to sell the same back to the seller at
a price other than the original price of purchase, or in the business of
purchasing personal property such as article made of or containing gold,
silver, platinum or other precious metals or jewels of any description for the
purpose of reducing or smelting them into any form different from their
condition or construction when purchased and reselling or marketing the
product.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in or carry on the business of a
pawnbroker in the City until he has first obtained a license to engage in and
carry on such business.  Every applicant for a license shall make an
application in writing to the Mayor, which application shall set forth the name
under which the business is to be conducted, the name and residence address of
every person interested in such business and the location at which the business
is to be carried on.  The application must be made by the person who is to
carry on the business and must contain references of at least two other
residents of the City as to the character of the applicant.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.03  RECORDS OF TRANSACTIONS; CONTENTS AND INSPECTION.
   A licensee shall keep a correct detailed list and description, in a book for
that purpose, of each article pledged or deposited with him, or on which
advances of money have been made, or which has been purchased by him.  He shall
also require such depositor or pledgor to sign his name and place of residence
in such books or upon a blank furnished for the purpose and shall also enter
the date and time when the deposit or pledge was made.  The pledgor shall also
reproduce thereon his right thumb print or left thumb print, if the right thumb
is missing, at the place indicated therefor in the book or on the back of such
card.  Such thumb print shall be reproduced and taken in the usual approved
manner and shall not be blurred or obliterated.  When any watch is pledged or
sold, he shall also write in such book the number of the movement, the number
of the case and the name of the maker thereof.  Where jewelry or gold or silver
articles of any kind are pledged or sold the licensee shall write in such book
all identifying letters or marks inscribed thereon.  The register shall also
contain an entry setting forth the interest to be charged on the amount of
money loaned.  Entries shall be written in ink in the English language and no
entry shall be erased, obliterated or defaced.  Such book at all times shall be
open to the inspection of the Mayor, Police Chief or any person authorized by
either of them.  Upon demand of any of them the licensee shall produce and show
any article thus listed and described which is in his possession.  Articles
found to be contraband, stolen or illegally obtained shall be deposited with
the Police Department to be held for evidence and return to the lawful owner,
if found, or otherwise disposed of as other found property hold by the Police
Department.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.04  SUBMISSION OF DAILY REPORT TO POLICE.
   A licensee shall prepare and deliver to the Police Chief or to any person
authorized by him, each work day, before the hour of 12:00 noon, a legible and
correct copy from such entries of the description of personal property, bonds,
notes or other securities received on deposit or purchased during the preceding
work day, with the time at which the article was received and a description of
the person by whom the article was left in pledge or from whom the article was
purchased.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.05  PAWNBROKER TO RETAIN GOODS FOR 72 HOURS; ALLEGEDLY STOLEN GOODS.
   (a)   A pawnbroker shall retain any and all goods or articles pledged with
him or purchased by him until the expiration of seventy-two hours after the
pledge or purchase was made.  The licensee may dispose of such goods or
articles or things sooner with the written permission of the Police Department.
   (b)   If the Police Chief, to whom the licensee made available the
information, has probable cause to believe that the article described therein
is stolen property, he shall notify the licensee in writing.  Upon receipt of
such a notice, the licensee shall retain the article until the expiration of
thirty days after the day on which he is first required to make available the
information, unless the Chief notifies the licensee in writing that he is not
required to retain the article until such expiration.
   (c)   If the Police Chief determines the identity of the true owner of the
allegedly stolen goods that have been purchased or pawned and are held by a
licensee, and informs the licensee of the true owner's identity:
      (1)   The licensee may restore the allegedly stolen goods to their true
owner directly.
      (2)   The true owner may reimburse the licensee for the amount the
licensee paid for the allegedly stolen goods.
      (3)   The true owner may recover the goods from the licensee in an action
at law.
   (d)   If the local authorities determine that the true owner of the
allegedly stolen goods, for whatever reason, chooses not to file a charge
against the person or persons allegedly responsible for the theft, the licensee
may charge the true owner of the allegedly stolen goods only the amount the
licensee paid or loaned for the allegedly stolen goods.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.06  PLEDGE FROM MINORS OR INTOXICATED PERSONS.
   No licensee shall take or receive in pawn or pledge for money lent, or take,
receive or purchase property, bonds, notes, securities or articles from a
minor, or the ownership of which is in or is claimed by a minor, or may be in
the possession or under the control of a minor, or a person appearing to be
intoxicated or under the influence of any drug, or known to be a notorious
thief, drug addict, pusher or illegal seller of habit forming drugs, or known
to have been convicted of larceny or burglary.
(Ord.  36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.07  PAWNING MECHANICS' TOOLS; PROOF OF OWNERSHIP.
   When any person presents to any pawnbroker for the purpose of pledging the
same as security for a loan, any implements or tools commonly used by
mechanics, the pawnbroker shall require such person to give proof that he is
the owner of the tools so offered as a pledge, and when the tools so offered
are stamped with a name or any initial or symbols the pawnbroker shall require
the person offering such tools or implements to produce the stamp by which such
name, initials or symbols were inprinted, or if unable to produce such stamp
such person shall be required to establish his identity.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.08  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Mayor, upon conviction of a person, firm or corporation for the
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any penal statute
relating to pawnbrokers, shall revoke the license.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
745.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree; for a second offense such person is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the second degree.
(Ord. 36, 1989.  Passed 6-6-89.)
CHAPTER 749
Itinerant Vendors and Hucksters
749.01   Itinerant vendor defined.
749.02   Scope.
749.03   Itinerant vendor's license required.
749.04   Itinerant vendor's license application.
749.05   Bond and appointment of agent for service.
749.06   Itinerant vendor's license issuance; fee.
749.07   Transfer and display of itinerant vendor's license.
749.08   False statements; responsibility of Mayor.
749.09   Huckster's license required.
749.10   Huckster's license fee.
749.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Peddlers and Solicitors - see BUS. REG. Ch.
713
      Secondhand stores - see BUS. REG. Ch.
783
 
 
749.01  ITINERANT VENDOR DEFINED.
   "Itinerant vendor" means and includes all persons, both principals and
agent, who engage in or conduct, in this State either in one locality or in
traveling from place to place, a temporary or transient business of selling
goods, wares and merchandise with the intention of continuing in such business
in any one place for a period of not more than 120 days, and who, for the
purpose of carrying on such business, hire, lease or occupy, either in whole or
in part, a room, building or other structure for the exhibition and sale of
such goods, wares and merchandise.  The fact that any store or place of
business has been or is to be leased for a period of less than 120 days shall
be in all cases prima facie evidence that the business is of a temporary or
transient character within the meaning of this chapter.
(1967 Code 749.03)
749.02  SCOPE.
   The provisions of Sections
749.01 through
749.08 shall not apply to any farmer or producer who sells any article,
provision or vegetable produced or grown by him, nor to the manufacture of any
article made or manufactured by him, nor to sales made to dealers by commercial
travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, nor to bona fide
sales of goods, wares or merchandise by sample for further delivery.
(1967 Code 749.04)
749.03  ITINERANT VENDOR'S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No itinerant vendor shall sell or offer for sale any goods, wares or
merchandise within the City, without first obtaining a license to do so
provided in this chapter.
(1967 Code 749.05)
749.04  ITINERANT VENDOR'S LICENSE APPLICATION.
   The application for the license required by Section
749.03, or an accompanying affidavit, shall be in writing and shall contain the
following facts:
   (a)   Reasons for, and character of, the temporary business which the
applicant desires to conduct.
   (b)   Names and addresses of persons from whom any goods, wares or
merchandise, which are intended for sale, were purchased.
   (c)   Name and address of the owner or person in whose interest the business
is being conducted.
   (d)   Places and dates where the applicant has been engaged in business for
the past eighteen months, together with the nature and character of such
business.
   (e)   All details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all goods,
wares and merchandise to be sold.
   (f)   The length of time for which the store or place where such goods,
wares or merchandise are to be sold, has been leased or is to be leased.
   Such facts as are set forth in the application or an accompanying affidavit,
shall be sworn to under oath before an officer empowered by the laws of this
State to take acknowledgment of deeds.
(1967 Code 749.06)
749.05  BOND AND APPOINTMENT OF AGENT FOR SERVICE.
   Before any license, as required by Section
749.03 is issued, the applicant shall:
   (a)   Execute and delivery to the Mayor a good and sufficient bond with good
and sufficient surety, to be approved by the Law Director, in the sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00).  Such bond shall be conditioned to indemnify or
reimburse any purchaser of goods, wares or merchandise in a sum equal to at
least the amount of any payment such purchaser may have been induced to make
through misrepresentation as to the kind, quality or value of such goods, wares
or merchandise, whether such misrepresentation was made by the owner or by his
servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale, or
through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated,
with reference to the stock of goods, wares and merchandise, or any part
thereof.
   (b)   File with the Mayor an instrument in writing, nominating and
appointing the Mayor, or the person performing the duties of such office, as
his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge the
service of notice of process for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to
any matters connected with or arising out of the license, and for the
performance of the condition of the bond required by this section, or for any
breach thereof, which instrument, in writing, so nominating and appointing the
Mayor as such agent, shall contain recitals to the effect that the applicant
for such license consents and agrees that the service of any notice or process
may be made upon his agent, and when so made shall be taken and held as valid
as if personally served upon the person apply for the license according to the
laws of this or any other State, and that the applicant waives all claim or
right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of
service.
      (1967 Code 749.07)
749.06  ITINERANT VENDOR'S LICENSE ISSUANCE; FEE.
   When all the requirements of Sections
749.01 to
749.08 have been met, and upon the payment of a fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each week or fraction thereof during which the applicant desires
to engage in business, the Mayor shall issue to such applicant a license
permitting him, for the period for which the license fee is paid, to sell in
temporary quarters, such goods, wares or merchandise as such itinerant vendor
may otherwise lawfully sell.
(1967 Code 749.08)
749.07  TRANSFER AND DISPLAY OF ITINERANT VENDOR'S LICENSE.
   No license issued under the provisions of Sections
749.01 to
749.08 shall be transferable, nor shall it be used by any person other than as
named in the license.  The licensee shall conspicuously display such license in
his place of business so that the same may be plainly visible to the public.
(1967 Code 749.09)
749.08  FALSE STATEMENTS; RESPONSIBILITY OF MAYOR.
   Any false or misleading statements made in the application or affidavit for
the license required by Section
749.03, or in any advertising matter, or orally by any person connected with
the licensee, issued or made to further the sale of merchandise, shall render
the license issued to the applicant making such false statements null and void,
and shall forfeit to the City the license fee already paid, and shall subject
such applicant to the full penalty provided in Section
749.99(b).
   Upon receiving complaints as to any such false or misleading statements, the
Mayor shall forthwith investigate and make demand for access to all books and
papers pertaining to the business of the licensee, which may assist the Mayor
in determining whether or not a false or misleading statement has been made. 
Further, the Mayor may put under oath any and all persons who may have any
connection with the business of the licensee, and command answers to any
questions that may be necessary to be propounded to get at the facts.
(1967 Code 749.10)
749.09  HUCKSTER'S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall carry on the business of a huckster or offer for sale or
sell upon any of the streets or public grounds of the City any fruit, vegetable
or farm produce of any kind without first having obtained from the Mayor a
license to do so.  This section shall not apply to any farmer, gardener, or
other person attempting in good faith to dispose of products of his own
raising.
(1967 Code 749.11)
749.10  HUCKSTER'S LICENSE FEE.
   A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged by the Mayor for the
license required by Section
749.09 and such license shall be good for a period of one year from the date of
issue.
(1967 Code 749.12)
749.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates Section
749.09 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.  Each day any violation continues
shall constitute a separate offense.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates Sections
749.01 through
749.08 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.  Each day that such
store or place of business is kept open and such sale conducted without the
license required in Section
749.03 or in excess of the period for which such license is issued and for
which such license has been paid, shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 753
Fortunetelling
753.01   Fortunetelling for a fee prohibited.
753.02   Seances for a fee prohibited.
753.03   Registration required.
753.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Petty theft - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
 
 
753.01  FORTUNETELLING FOR A FEE PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm, corporation or unincorporated association shall charge a
fee for practice in the City of fortunetelling or pretending to foretell future
events or engaging in any manner in the practice of fortunetelling future
events or prophesying the future, nor hold out to the public that such
practices are available for a fee.  This section applies to the practices
named, regardless of the name given to such practice, such practices as palm
reading, card reading, horoscope reading and all such similar practices being
included within the prohibition.
753.02  SEANCES FOR A FEE PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm, corporation or unincorporated association shall charge a
fee for conducting, within the City the practice of communicating, attempting
to communicate or pretending to communicate with departed spirits in a ritual
generally referred to as "seances".
753.03  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation or unincorporated association shall practice in
the City, without charging a fee, any of those things which would be prohibited
by Sections
753.01 and
753.02 if a fee were to be charged, unless and until such person, firm,
corporation or unincorporated association shall first have registered with the
Chief of Police.  Forms for registration shall be provided by the Chief and
shall be issued free of charge.
753.99  PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation or unincorporated association who violates
this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
CHAPTER 760
Adult Entertainment Businesses
760.01   Purpose.
760.02   Definitions.
760.03   License requirement.
760.04   Issuance of permit and/or license.
760.05   Expiration of permit and/or license.
760.06   License suspension.
760.07   License revocation.
760.08   Transfer of permit and/or license.
760.09   Location regulations.
760.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Indecency and obscenity - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
533
 
 
760.01  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety and
welfare through the regulation of adult entertainment businesses.  It is the
intent of these sections to regulate entertainment businesses, as defined
herein, so to prevent crime, to protect the City's retail trade and property
values, and in general, to preserve the quality of life in the City and not to
suppress First Amendment rights of speech.  (Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.02  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Adult entertainment business" means an adult bookstore, adult motion
picture theater, adult peep show, or an adult entertainment establishment as
further defined in this section.
   (b)   "Adult bookstore" means an establishment which utilizes a substantial
or significant portion of its retail selling area for the purpose of retail
sale or rental, or for the purpose of display by coin or slug-operated or
electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture
machines, projectors or other image-producing devices, or both, books,
magazines, other periodicals, films, tapes and cassettes which are
distinguished by their emphasis on adult materials as defined in this section.
   (c)   "Adult motion picture theater" means an establishment wherein motion
pictures are shown which present material distinguished or characterized by an
emphasis on matter depicting, describing or related to adult material as
defined in this section.
   (d)   "Adult peep show" means an enclosed building used for presenting
material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting,
describing or relating to adult material as defined in this section, for
observation by patrons therein by means of coin or slug- operated viewing
devices.
   (e)   "Adult entertainment establishment" means a bar, nightclub, restaurant
or similar establishment which regularly features person(s) who appear in a
state of nudity or live performances which are characterized by exhibitions,
dance routines or gyrational choreography of persons totally nude, topless,
bottomless or stripers or similar entertainment or services which constitute
adult material as defined in this section.
   (f)   "Adult material" means any book, magazine, newspaper, pamphlet.
poster, print, picture, slide, transparency, figure, image, description, motion
picture film. videotape, phonograph record or tape, other tangible thing or
service, capable of arousing interest through sight, sound or touch, and:
      (1)   Which material is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis 
on  matter  displaying,  describing  or representing sexual activity,
masturbation, sexual excitement,  nudity,  bestiality  or human  bodily
functions of elimination; or
      (2)   Which service is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on
sexual activity, masturbation, sexual excitement,  nudity, bestiality  or 
human  bodily functions of elimination.  (Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.03  LICENSE REQUIREMENT.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for a person to operate an adult entertainment
business without a valid permit and/or license, issued by the Office of
Planning and Development.
   (b)   An application for a permit and/or license must be made on a form
provided by the City.  The application must be accompanied by a sketch or a
diagram showing the configuration of the premises including a statement of
total floor space occupied by the business. The sketch or diagram need not be
professionally prepared but must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with
marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or
minus six inches.
   (c)   The applicant must be qualified according to the provisions of this
chapter and the premises must be inspected and found to be in compliance with
the law by the Health Department, Fire Department, Building Official, and
Zoning Official.
   (d)   If a person wishes to operate an adult entertainment business as an
individual, he must sign the application for a permit and/or license as
applicant. If a person who wishes to operate an adult entertainment business is
other than an individual, each individual who has ten  percent (10%) or greater
interest in the business must sign the application for a permit and/or license
as applicant. If a corporation is listed as owner of an adult entertainment
business or as the entity which wishes to operate such a business, each
individual having a ten percent  (10%) or greater interest in the corporation
must sign the application for a permit and/or license as applicant.
   (e)   The fact that a person possesses other types of State or City permits
and/or licenses does not exempt him from the requirement of obtaining an adult
entertainment business permit and/or license.
   (f)   Applications for a permit, whether original or renewal, must be made
to the Office of Planning and Development by the intended operator of the
enterprise.  Applications must be submitted by hand delivery to the Office of
Planning and Development or the designee during regular working hours.
Application forms shall be supplied by the Office of Planning and Development.
The intended operator shall be required to give the following information on
the application form:
      (1)   A.   The name, street address (and mailing address, if different)
and Ohio driver's license number of the intended operator;
   B.   The name and street address (and mailing address, if different) of the
owner(s);
      (2)   The name under which the establishment is to be operated and a
general description of the services to be provided;
      (3)   The telephone number of the establishment;
      (4)   The address, and legal description of the tract of land on which
the establishment is to be located;
      (5)   If the establishment is in operation. the date on which the owner
(s) acquired the establishment for which the permit is sought. and  the date
on  which  the establishment  began  operations  as  an  adult entertainment
business at the location for which the permit is sought; and
      (6)   If the establishment is not in operation, the expected startup date
(which shall be expressed in number of days from the date of issuance of the
permit). If the expected startup date is to be more than ten days following the
date of issuance of the permit, then a detailed explanation of the
construction, repair or remodeling work or other cause of the expected delay
and a statement or the owner's time schedule and plan for accomplishing the
same.
   (g)   The application shall be accompanied by the following:
      (1)   Payment of the application fee in full;
      (2)   If the establishment is an Ohio corporation, a certified copy of
the articles of incorporation, together with all amendments thereto;
      (3)   If the establishment is a foreign corporation, a certified copy of
the certificate of authority to transact business in this State, together with
all amendments thereto;
      (4)   If the establishment is a limited partnership formed under the law
of Ohio, a certified copy of the certificate of limited partnership, together
with all amendments thereto;
      (5)   If the establishment is a foreign limited partnership, a certified
copy of the certificate of limited partnership and the qualification documents,
together with all amendments thereto;
      (6)   Proof of the current fee ownership of the tract of land on which
the establishment is to be situated in the form of a copy of the recorded deed;
      (7)   If the persons identified as the fee owner(s) of the tract of land
in item (6) are not also the owners of the establishment, then the lease,
purchase contract, purchase option contract, lease option contract or other
document(s) evidencing the legally enforceable right of the owners or proposed
owners of the establishment to have or obtain the use and possession of the
tract or portion thereof that is to be used for the establishment for the
purpose of the operation of the establishment;
      (8)   Any of items (2) through (7), above shall not be required for a
renewal application if the applicant states that the documents previously
furnished the Office of Planning and Development with the original application
or previous renewals thereof remain correct and current.
   (h)   The application shall contain a statement under oath that:
      (I)   The  applicant  has  personal  knowledge  of  the information
contained  in the application and that the information contained therein and
furnished therewith is true and correct; and,
      (2)   The applicant has read the provisions of this chapter.
   (i)   A separate application and permit shall be required for each adult
entertainment business.  (Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.04  ISSUANCE OF PERMIT AND/OR LICENSE.
   (a)   The Office of Planning and Development shall approve the issuance of a
permit and/or license to an applicant within thirty days after receipt of an
application unless he finds one or more of the following to be true:
      (1)   An applicant is under eighteen years of age;
      (2)   An applicant or an applicant's spouse is overdue in his payment to
the City of taxes, fines, or penalties assessed against him or imposed upon him
in relation to an adult entertainment business;
      (3)   An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary
for issuance of the permit and/or license or has falsely answered a question or
request for information on the application form;
      (4)   An applicant is residing with a person who has been denied a permit
and/or license by the City to operate an adult entertainment business within
the preceding twelve months, or residing with a person whose license to operate
an adult entertainment business has been revoked within the preceding twelve
months.
      (5)   The premises to be used for the adult entertainment business have
not been approved by the Health Department, Fire Department, Building Official
and Zoning Official as being in compliance with applicable law and ordinances.
      (6)   The permit and/or license fee required by this chapter has not been
paid.
      (7)   An application of the proposed establishment is in violation of or
is not in compliance with any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   The permit and/or license, if granted, shall state on its face the
name of the person or persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date, and
the address of the adult entertainment business. The permit and/or license
shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the adult
entertainment business so that it may be easily read at any time.
   (c)   The Health Department, Fire Department, Building Official and Zoning
Official shall complete their certification that the premises is in compliance
or not in the compliance within twenty days of receipt of the application by
the Office of Planning and Development. The certification shall be promptly
presented to the Office of Planning and Development.
   (d)   In the event that the Office of Planning and Development determines
that an applicant is not eligible for a permit, the applicant shall be given
notice in writing of the reasons for the denial within forty five days of the
receipt of its application by the Office of Planning and Development, provided
that the applicant my request, in writing, that such period be extended for an
additional period of not more than ten days at any time before the notice is
issued in order to make modifications necessary to comply with this chapter.
   (e)   An applicant my appeal the decision of the Office of Planning and
Development regarding a denial to the Board of Zoning Appeals by filing a
written notice of appeal with the City secretary within fifteen days after the
applicant is given notice of the Office of Planning and Development's decision.
The notice of appeal shall be accompanied by a memorandum or other writing
setting out fully the grounds for such appeal and all arguments in support
thereof. The Office of Planning and Development may submit a memorandum in
response to the memorandum filed by the applicant on appeal to the Board of
Zoning Appeals. After reviewing such memoranda, as well as the Office of
Planning and Development's written decision, if any, and exhibits submitted to
the Office of Planning and Development, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall vote
to either uphold or overrule the Office of Planning and Development's decision
after the date on which the City secretary receives the notice of appeal.
However, all parties shall be required to comply with the Office of Planning
and Development's decision during the pendency of the appeal.
   (f)   Fees.  The annual fee for an adult entertainment business permit and/
or license is five hundred dollars ($500).  This fee is to be used to pay for
the cost of administration and enforcement of this chapter.
   (g)   Inspection.  An applicant, or permittee and/or licensee shall permit
representative of the Police Department, Health Department, Fire Department,
Zoning Department or other City or State departments or agencies to inspect the
premises of an adult entertainment business for the purpose of insuring
compliance with the law, at any time it is occupied or open for business.
(Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.05  EXPIRATION OF PERMIT AND/OR LICENSE.
   (a)   Each permit and/or license shall expire one year from the date of
issuance and may be renewed only by making application as provided in Section
760.03. Application for renewal should be made at least thirty days before the
expiration date, and when made less than thirty days before the expiration
date, the expiration of the permit and/or license will not be affected.
   (b)   When the Office of Planning and Development denies renewal of a
license, the applicant shall not be issued a permit and/or license for one year
from the date of denial. If subsequent to denial, the Office of Planning and
Development finds that the basis for denial of the renewal permit and/or
license has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a permit
and/or license if at least ninety days have elapsed since the date denial
became final.
(Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.06  LICENSE SUSPENSION.
   The Office of Planning and Development shall suspend a permit and/or license
for a period not to exceed thirty days if he determines that permittee and/or
licensee or an employee of a permittee and/or licensee has:
   (a)   Violated or is not in compliance with any section of this chapter;
   (b)   Become impaired or intoxicated through the use of alcoholic beverages
while on the adult entertainment business premises;
   (c)   Refused to allow the inspection of the adult entertainment business
premises as authorized by this chapter;
   (d)   Knowingly permitted gambling by any  person on  the adult
entertainment business premises.  (Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.07  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   (a)   The Office of Planning and Development shall revoke a permit and/or
license if a cause of suspension in Section
760.06  occurs and the permit and/or license has been suspended within the
proceeding twelve months.
   (b)   The Office of Planning and Development shall also revoke a permit and/
or license if he determines that:
      (1)   A permittee and/or licensee gave false or misleading information in
the material submitted during the application process;
      (2)   A permittee and/or licensee or an employee has knowingly  allowed 
possession,  use,  or  sale  of controlled substances on the premises;
      (3)   A permittee and/or licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed
prostitution on the premises;
      (4)   A permittee and or licensee or an employee knowingly operated the
adult entertainment business during a period of time when the permittee's and/
or licensee's permit and or license was suspended;
      (5)   A permittee and/or licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed
any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, or other
sexual conduct to occur in or on the permitted and/or licensed premises;
      (6)   A permittee and/or licensee is delinquent in payment to the City or
State for any taxes for fees past due;
      (7)   The owner or operator of the permitted establishment knowingly
allowed a person under eighteen years of age to enter an establishment; or
      (8)   That there was a change of owner or operator for which a transfer
application was not timely filed.
   (c)   When the Office of Planning and Development revokes a permit and/or
license, the revocation shall continue for one year, and the permittee and or
licensee shall not be issued an adult entertainment permit and/or license for
one year from the date revocation became effective. If, subsequent to
revocation, the Office of Planning and Development finds that the basis for the
revocation has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a permit
and/or license if at least ninety days have elapsed since the date the
revocation became effective.
   (d)   After denial of an application by the Office of Planning and
Development and the Board of Zoning Appeals, or denial of a renewal of an
application, or suspension or revocation of a permit and/or license by the
Office of Planning and Development, the applicant or licensee or permittee may
seek prompt judicial review of such administrative action in any court of
competent jurisdiction. The administrative action shall be promptly reviewed by
the court.
(Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.08  TRANSFER OF PERMIT AND/OR LICENSE.
   A permittee and/or licensee shall not transfer his permit and/or license to
another, nor shall a permittee and/or licensee operate an adult entertainment
business under the authority of a permit and/or license at any place other than
the address designated in the application.
(Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.09  LOCATION REGULATIONS.
   Adult entertainment businesses shall be permitted in any commercially-zoned
district provided that:
   (a)   The adult entertainment business shall not be operated or located
within  radius of 1000 feet of:
      (1)   A church, synagogue or regular place of religious worship;
      (2)   A public or private school, library or teaching facility;
      (3)   A boundary of any area zoned for residential use;
      (4)   A public park or recreational facility;
      (5)   A licensed day-care center;
      (6)   Establishments for the sale of beer or intoxicating liquor for
consumption on the premises;
      (7)   Pool or billiard halls;
      (8)   Pinball halls or arcades;
      (9)   Dance halls or discotheques;
      (10)   Another adult entertainment business.
   (b)   All building openings, entries and windows for adult entertainment
businesses shall be located, covered or screened in such a manner as to prevent
a view into the interior from any public or semi-public place or area.
   (c)   Advertisements, displays or other promotional materials shall not be
shown or exhibited so as to be visible to the public from pedestrian sidewalks
or from other public or semi-public places or areas.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful to allow a person who is younger than eighteen
years of age to enter or be on the premises of an adult entertainment business.
      (Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
760.99  PENALTY.
   A person who operates or causes to be operated an adult entertainment
business without a valid license or otherwise violates any provision of this
chapter is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for the
criminal violation. Such criminal violation shall be punishable by a fine of up
to one thousand dollars ($1,000) and/or imprisonment for up to sixty days.
(Ord. 55, 1994.  Passed 11-21-94.)
CHAPTER 761
Pool, Billiards and Bowling
761.01   Clear view of premises required; exemption.
761.02   Card games on premises.
761.03   Gambling on premises.
761.04   Business hours for pool rooms.
761.05   Business hours for bowling alleys.
761.06   License required.
761.07   Qualifications of applicant.
761.08   Authority of Mayor.
761.09   License application.
761.10   License issuance.
761.11   License fee.
761.12   License revocation.
761.13   Posting license.
761.14   License transfer.
761.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
      Gambling generally - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
      Liquor control - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
529
 
 
761.01  CLEAR VIEW OF PREMISES REQUIRED; EXEMPTION.
   Any room or place in which any pool or billiard table or bowling alley is
located for profit shall be so constructed and maintained that a clear view of
the interior of such place may be had from the street on which such place of
business is located.  Such room or place shall be free from any screens,
partitions, fixtures or obstructions which may interfere with a clear view from
such street.  The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any
room or place not located on the ground floor or which does not directly front
or abut any street.
(1967 Code 761.01)
761.02  CARD GAMES ON PREMISES.
   No card game of any kind shall be permitted in any room or place used as a
bowling alley or poolroom.
(1967 Code 761.02)
761.03  GAMBLING ON PREMISES.
   No owner or operator of any poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley shall
permit to be played, nor shall anyone present therein play, any game upon any
table or alley for money or other valuable thing whatever, nor shall they
permit or engage in the playing of cards, the operation of punchboards, the
operation of raffling devices, the use of a pea ball or other game of chance or
any form of gambling whatever, in any billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley,
or in any room where pool or billiard tables or bowling alleys are located.
(1967 Code 761.03)
761.04  BUSINESS HOURS FOR POOL ROOMS.
   No owner, proprietor, agent or person in charge of any pool room which
operates under a liquor license shall harbor, permit or allow any person to
remain in any such pool room between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.,
Monday through Saturday, other than necessary help or labor therein required,
or except for work of necessity or charity.  Should a pool room be operating
without a liquor license, the permissive business hours may be extended to 12:
00 midnight.  Sunday hours shall be from noon to 11:00 p.m.  The provisions as
to Sunday shall not extend to persons who consciously observe another day of
the week as the Sabbath and abstain from doing the things herein prohibited on
Sunday.
(Ord. 47, 1990.  Passed 8-6-90.)
761.05  BUSINESS HOURS FOR BOWLING ALLEYS.
   No person, being the owner, licensee, keeper or having charge of any bowling
alley within the City shall keep the same in use and operation between the
hours of 2:30 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday to Saturday both inclusive, and
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 2:00 p.m. on Sunday, except that the
owner, licensee, keeper or employee may lawfully clean, wax, polish or
otherwise repair such alleys immediately after closing time.  However, the
extension of time after midnight shall not be construed to be an exemption to
Chapter
509 prohibiting loud and unnecessary noises.
(Ord. 18, 1960.)
761.06  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, as owner, proprietor, agent or person in charge thereof, shall
maintain, keep or conduct, or cause, permit or allow to be maintained, kept or
conducted, for profit, within the City, any billiard or pool table, or any
bowling or pin and ball alley, without obtaining a license as provided in this
chapter.
(1967  Code 761.06)
761.07  QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT.
   Every applicant for a license required by this chapter shall possess the
following qualifications:
   (a)   He must be at least eighteen years of age.
   (b)   He must be a citizen of the United State or shall have declared his
intention through the proper procedure to become a citizen.
   (c)   He must be of good moral character and a suitable person to engage in
such business.
   (d)   He shall not have been convicted of a felony, or of any offense under
the laws of the United States, or of this State, or the ordinances of the City
relating to traffic in intoxicating liquors.
   The Mayor may refuse to issue any license required by this chapter.
(1967  Code 761.07)
761.08  AUTHORITY OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to issue a license to any suitable person to
maintain, keep or conduct, for profit, one or more billiard or pool tables or
bowling or pin and ball alleys within the City.
(1967 Code 761.08)
761.09  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for the license required by this chapter shall be made in
writing upon blanks furnished by the Mayor, and the application shall contain:
   (a)   The full name of the applicant;
   (b)   His address;
   (c)   The name of his former or present employer, if any;
   (d)   The names of two persons who may be referred to as to such applicant's
character;
   (e)   The number of tables and alleys to be so used;
   (f)   The location and a description of the room or place to be so occupied;
   (g)   The applicant's own statement as to whether or not he has ever been
convicted of any offense under the laws of the United States, or of this State
or the ordinances of the City relating to traffic in intoxicating liquors, and
shall be signed by or for such applicant.
   Such application shall be filed with the Mayor.
   (1967 Code 761.09)
761.10  LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   If the applicant for the license required by this chapter is of good moral
character and is a suitable person to engage in such business, the Mayor shall,
upon payment of the fee required by Section
761.11, issue within ten days from the time such written application is filed
with him, a license to such applicant.
(1967 Code 761.10)
761.11  LICENSE FEE.
   For any license required by the provisions of this chapter, the fee of ten
dollars ($10.00) for one such billiard or pool table, and ten dollars ($10.00)
for one bowling or pin and ball alley, shall be required.  The further sum of
five dollars ($5.00) shall be required for each additional billiard or pool
table and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional bowling or pin and ball
alley.  The fee shall be paid in advance at the time such license is issued.
   All such licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year.
   If any license is granted for a period of less than twelve months, the
license fee shall be prorated accordingly.
   If any license fee is wrongfully and unlawfully required or exacted and paid
hereunder, it may be recovered by the person paying it.
(1967 Code 761.11)
761.12  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked at
any time by the Mayor on satisfactory proof that a violation of the laws of the
United States, this State, or any provision of this chapter or any ordinances
of the City relating to traffic in intoxicating liquors has been caused,
permitted, suffered or negligently or carelessly allowed on the premises by the
licensee or person in charge thereof.  Such license may also be revoked upon
the conviction of the licensee of a felony.
   When any such license has been revoked, no new license shall be issued to
the same person until after the expiration of at least one year.
   In case of revocation, there shall be returned to the licensee the unearned
portion of his license fee.
(1967 Code 761.12)
761.13  POSTING LICENSE.
   The license required by this chapter shall at all times be posted in a
conspicuous place in the room or place where any pool or billiard table or
bowling alley is maintained, kept or conducted.
(1967 Code 761.13)
761.14  LICENSE TRANSFER.
   Any license issued according to this chapter shall not be sold, assigned or
transferred by the licensee to any other person and shall be void in the hands
of any person other than the one to whom it is issued.
(1967 Code 761.14)
761.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of Sections
761.01 through
761.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates any provisions of Sections
761.06 to
761.14 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree for a second or any subsequent offense.  Upon conviction
of a second or any subsequent offense, in addition to the penalties herein
provided, the license then held by the person convicted may be revoked by the
Mayor.
